objective: To introduce the concept of money and its purpose.
explanation:
• Money is a tool we use to exchange goods and services.
• It has different forms, such as coins and bills.
• Each coin and bill has a specific value.

activity1.title: Money Sorting
materials: Mix of real or play Indian coins and bills
steps: Provide a mix of ₹1, ₹2, ₹5, ₹10 coins and ₹10, ₹20, ₹50 bills.
Ask the child to separate coins and bills into two groups.
Further sort them by value.
Encourage the child to count each group aloud.

activity2.title: Shopping Pretend Play
steps: Set up a pretend store.
Give the child play money.
Let them “buy” items.
Practice giving money and receiving change.

objective: To learn about different coins and bills and their values.
explanation:
• Introduce common coins and bills used in your country.
• Explain the value of each coin and bill.
• Demonstrate how to count money using different combinations.

activity1.title: Coin Recognition Game
materials: Real or play coins and bills
steps: Show the child a coin or bill.
Ask them to name its value.
Match it to the correct space on the chart.

activity2.title: Money Matching
materials: Pairs of coins/bills or matching cards.
steps: Lay out the cards face down.
Take turns flipping cards to find matches.
Match same values together.

objective: To understand the difference between spending and saving money.
explanation:
• Spending means using money to buy things.
• Saving means keeping money for later.
• Both are important for smart decisions.

activity1.title: Piggy Bank Challenge
steps: Give child coins daily/weekly.
Ask them to drop part of it into the piggy bank.
Track savings on a chart.

activity2.title: Spending vs. Saving Game
steps: Show child a toy they want.
Offer small amount of play money.
Discuss if they want to spend now or save for a bigger toy.

objective: To introduce the concept of budgeting and planning spending.
explanation:
• A budget is a plan for money use.
• It helps us make smart choices.
• We list income and expenses.

activity1.title: Create a Simple Budget
steps: List categories (food, toys, savings).
Allocate amounts to each.
Draw and decorate a simple chart.

activity2.title: Budgeting Game
steps: Give the child limited play money.
Let them "shop" within budget.
Ask questions about their choices.

objective: To learn how to shop on a budget and make smart choices.
explanation:
• Compare prices and choose wisely.
• Make a list to avoid extra purchases.
• Stick to the budget when shopping.

activity1.title: Grocery Store Field Trip
steps: Create a basic list with the child.
Visit a local store.
Let the child help choose items within budget.

activity2.title: Shopping List Game
steps: Child uses list to “shop.”
Stick to items only on the list.

objective: To practice counting money accurately.
explanation:
• Add coin and bill values.
• Count slowly and carefully.
• Combine coins to make larger values.

activity1.title: Money Counting Game
steps: Child receives mixed denominations.
Count each pile’s total.
Double-check using a calculator.

activity2.title: Real-Life Transactions
steps: Assign a price to real snacks.
Have child “buy” them using exact change.

objective: To set and achieve financial goals.
explanation:
• Goals give purpose to saving.
• We track progress to stay motivated.
• Goals can be big or small.

activity1.title: Goal Setting Worksheet
steps: Ask child to draw or write a goal.
Add steps to reach the goal.
Decorate for motivation.

activity2.title: Savings Challenge
steps: Choose an amount to save each day/week.
Mark progress on calendar.
Celebrate when goal is met.

objective: To understand the difference between good and bad debt.
explanation:
• Good debt helps reach goals.
• Bad debt causes problems.
• Be responsible with borrowing.

activity1.title: Debt Scenario Game
steps: Read a situation (e.g., borrowing for school).
Ask child if it’s good or bad debt.
Discuss why.

activity2.title: Debt Consequences Discussion
steps: Talk about what happens if someone doesn’t repay debt.
Use age-appropriate stories.

objective: To teach the importance of financial responsibility.
explanation:
• Make smart choices with money.
• Avoid impulse buys.
• Save for the future.

activity1.title: Financial Decision-Making Game
steps: Present a situation (buy candy or save?).
Child chooses and explains why.
Discuss better options.

activity2.title: Financial Responsibility Pledge
steps: Child writes or draws how they’ll be responsible.
Sign and display.

objective: To introduce the concept of long-term financial planning.
explanation:
• Planning helps reach big goals.
• Start early to build habits.
• Think about future needs.

activity1.title: Future Planning Exercise
steps: Ask what the child wants to be when grown up.
Draw or write the dream.
Discuss what money they’ll need.

activity2.title: Financial Role-Playing
steps: Child acts as an adult buying groceries, paying bills.
Use pretend money.

objective: Introduce the concept of earning money through work or chores.
explanation:
• People earn money by doing work or chores.
• Earning money helps us buy things or save for future needs.
• Work can be fun and rewarding.

activity1.title: Pretend Job Play
steps: Set up different “jobs” like cooking, cleaning, or fixing things.
Assign tasks and offer pretend payment for completion.
Let the child collect money after each job.
activity1.achievement: Understanding that work can earn money.

activity2.title: Chore Reward Chart
steps: Create a weekly chart listing age-appropriate chores.
Set a pretend amount of money earned for each chore.
Add a sticker every time a chore is completed.
Exchange stickers for pretend money at the end of the week.

objective: Differentiate between needs (essential items) and wants (desirable items).
explanation:
• Needs are things we must have to live (like food, clothes, and shelter).
• Wants are things we would like but don’t need to survive.
• It's important to spend money on needs before wants.

activity1.title: Needs vs. Wants Sorting
steps: Show each picture and ask if it's a need or a want.
Sort pictures into “Need” and “Want” bowls.
Talk through the reason behind each placement.
activity1.achievement: Understanding the difference between needs and wants.

activity2.title: Budget Shopping Role Play
steps: Give the child a limited budget.
Present a mix of needs and wants in a pretend store.
Let the child decide what to buy first.
Discuss choices afterward.

objective: Explore different saving strategies.
explanation:
• Saving helps us reach future goals.
• We can use different tools like piggy banks or savings jars.
• Having a plan makes saving easier.

activity1.title: Piggy Bank Goal Setting
steps: Ask the child to draw something they want to save for (e.g., a toy).
Label the jar with the goal.
Add coins every time money is “earned.”

activity2.title: Saving Jar Categories
steps: Introduce the concept of dividing money into categories.
Have the child sort money into the jars with explanations.
Revisit weekly to check progress.

objective: Practice counting money and making change.
explanation:
• Making change means giving back the right amount of money after a purchase.
• It helps us understand how much things cost.
• It's a fun way to practice math.

activity1.title: Play Shop Transactions
steps: Set up a shop with price-labeled items.
Child “buys” items with play money.
Practice calculating and giving back change.

activity2.title: Make the Right Change
steps: Set prices and give the child an amount that requires change.
Let the child calculate the right coins to return.
Check and discuss.

objective: Learn about different currencies around the world.
explanation:
• Different countries use different types of money called currency.
• Each currency has its own name, symbol, and value.
• It’s fun to learn about money from other places.

activity1.title: World Money Exploration
steps: Match currency images to countries on the map.
Talk about symbols and values.
Compare how they look different from Indian currency.

activity2.title: Currency Exchange Pretend Play
steps: Set up a travel booth with pretend exchange rates.
Have the child “travel” and exchange Indian currency.
Use new currency to “buy” items from that country.

objective: Recognize persuasive language and sales tactics in advertisements.
explanation:
• Ads try to make us want to buy things.
• They use bright colors, catchy words, and fun characters.
• It's important to think before buying something we see in an ad.

activity1.title: Ad Detective
steps: Cut out ads and identify catchy words or visuals.
Discuss what the ad is trying to make you do.
Sort into “Honest” or “Persuasive.”

activity2.title: Make Your Own Honest Ad
steps: Ask the child to pick an item to “sell.”
Help them create an ad that shows the real features, not exaggerations.
Present to family or friends.

objective: Create a basic budget for specific needs or wants.
explanation:
• A budget helps us plan how to use our money.
• We can divide our money into different parts—spending, saving, and giving.
• Budgeting helps us make smart choices.

activity1.title: Trip Budget Planning
steps: Choose a pretend destination.
Assign prices to travel, food, and fun items.
Let the child divide money based on priority.

activity2.title: My Pocket Money Plan
steps: Ask what the child would do with ₹100.
Help split the amount among the columns.
Talk through each choice.

objective: Introduce the concept of credit cards and responsible usage.
explanation:
• A credit card lets you borrow money to pay later.
• We must always pay back what we borrow, or we’ll owe more.
• It’s important to use credit responsibly.

activity1.title: Credit Card Simulation
steps: Role-play shopping with a pretend card.
Keep a written note of what is “owed.”
Repay using play money.

activity2.title: Good vs. Bad Credit Choices
materials: buying food vs. toys with credit).
steps: Read each card aloud.
Ask the child to decide if it’s a smart use of credit.
Discuss why or why not.

objective: Develop critical thinking when comparing prices and offers.
explanation:
• Sometimes the same item costs different amounts in different places.
• Comparing prices helps us get the best deal.
• Coupons and discounts help save money.

activity1.title: Price Tag Hunt
materials: Same item with different prices (real or pretend)
steps: Show the same toy at different prices.
Let the child compare and choose the best value.
Talk about “why” choices were made.

activity2.title: Coupon Sorting Game
steps: Sort coupons by usefulness for needs vs. wants.
Match the best coupon to different items.

objective: Introduce the basic idea of taxes and their purpose.
explanation:
• Taxes are money we pay to help the community.
• Taxes pay for things like roads, schools, and parks.
• Everyone pays a little to help everyone.

activity1.title: Sales Tax Pretend Play
steps: Child buys items with marked prices.
Add a fixed tax per item.
Collect and count total money.

activity2.title: Where Taxes Go Discussion
steps: Match public services to the concept of tax funding.
Role-play being a community helper funded by taxes.

objective: Introduce the concept of investing and its potential benefits.
explanation:
• Investing means putting money into something that can grow over time. 
• People invest in things like stocks or businesses. 
• Investing can have risks and rewards.

activity1.title: Stock Market Simulation:
activity1.achievement: •  Kids understand the concept of buying low and selling high.

objective: Create a comprehensive budget and financial plan.
explanation:
• A budget helps us plan how to use money wisely. 
• Financial planning means thinking about both now and the future. 
• We can set goals and track our spending.

activity1.title: Monthly Budget Worksheet:
activity1.achievement: •  Kids understand how to plan spending.

activity2.title: Financial Planning Game:
activity2.achievement: •  Learn how choices affect financial goals.

objective: Explain the concept of compound interest and its power for growth.
explanation:
• Compound interest means you earn interest on both your savings and the interest it earns. 
• The more time you save, the more money you can grow. 
• It's a great way to build wealth over time.

activity1.title: Compound Interest Calculator:
activity1.achievement: •  Understand how money grows faster with compound interest.

objective: Develop critical thinking skills to make informed consumer decisions.
explanation:
• Ads try to influence our choices by showing exciting images and words. 
• Smart consumers ask questions and compare before buying. 
• Thinking ahead helps us make better decisions.

activity2.title: Comparison Shopping:
materials: •  Flyers or online ads for same item at different prices.

objective: Set long-term financial goals and create a plan to achieve them.
explanation:
• A goal is something we want to reach in the future. 
• Financial goals help us decide what to save for. 
• Planning helps us take small steps to reach big dreams.

objective: Understand the importance of credit and responsible debt management.
explanation:
• Credit means borrowing money that we have to pay back. 
• Debt is what we owe when we use credit. 
• It's important to borrow wisely and pay back on time.

objective: Introduce reliable sources for financial information and education.
explanation:
• Financial knowledge helps us make better money choices. 
• Banks, websites, and books can teach us about money. 
• Learning never stops!

activity2.title: Online Resources:
activity2.achievement: •  Know where to find trustworthy info.

objective: Recognize common financial scams and protect personal information.
explanation:
• Some people try to trick others to steal their money. 
• Scams can come by phone, email, or messages. 
• We should always be careful with personal information.

activity2.title: Safe Online Practices:
activity2.achievement: •  Learn and teach good digital habits.

objective: Understand the concept of philanthropy and responsible giving.
explanation:
• Giving to others can help people and make us feel good. 
• We can share a portion of our money, time, or items. 
• It’s important to choose charities we care about.

activity1.title: Charity Research:
activity1.achievement: •  Learn how to choose a cause.

objective: Explore the idea of financial independence and entrepreneurship.
explanation:
• Financial independence means being able to take care of your own money needs. 
• Entrepreneurship is starting your own business to earn money. 
• Entrepreneurs solve problems and take smart risks.

topic: The Economy and How It Works
objective: Introduce the basics of how the economy functions.
explanation:
• The economy is how people make, buy, and sell things.
• Everyone has a role: workers, businesses, and consumers.
• We use money to buy goods (things) and services (help from others).

activity1.title: Community Role Game
activity1.achievement: Children understand the roles in an economy

activity2.title: Goods and Services Sorting
activity2.achievement: Identify examples of goods and services

objective: Teach decision-making when choosing how to spend money.
explanation:
• Money is limited, so we must make smart choices.
• Comparing prices, quality, and needs vs. wants helps us spend wisely.
• Waiting before buying can help avoid impulse buying.

activity1.title: Price Comparison Activity
materials: Printouts or real items with prices
activity1.achievement: Ability to choose value over price

topic: The Value of Time and Money
objective: Help children understand that time is also a valuable resource.
explanation:
• We often trade time for money (working).
• Time management helps us do more with less stress.
• Balancing work, rest, and fun is important.

activity1.title: Time Budgeting Activity
activity1.achievement: Awareness of how we spend time

objective: Explore different jobs and how people earn income.
explanation:
• Jobs are how people earn money by helping others or creating things.
• Some jobs earn hourly wages, some earn salaries.
• Different jobs have different income levels.

activity1.title: Career Exploration Game
activity1.achievement: Recognize a variety of careers and how they earn

objective: Learn how banks work and why people use them.
explanation:
• Banks keep our money safe.
• We can deposit, withdraw, and even earn interest on savings.
• Banks help with loans and payments too.

objective: Introduce digital money and staying safe online.
explanation:
• Digital money is used through apps and cards.
• Online purchases need to be safe and secure.
• Personal information should never be shared online.

activity2.title: Password Safety Activity
materials: Worksheet with password do's and don'ts

objective: Help kids create and run a small business project.
explanation:
• A business provides goods or services in exchange for money.
• Businesses need a plan, supplies, and customers.
• Profit is what you earn after paying for costs.

objective: Understand that every money decision has potential risks and rewards.
explanation:
• Taking risks can lead to rewards or losses.
• It's important to think before spending or investing.
• Some risks are smart, others should be avoided.

objective: Encourage collaboration and generosity in financial decisions.
explanation:
• Sometimes we share money or team up to buy things.
• Working with others helps us learn patience and cooperation.
• Giving can make a positive impact.

activity1.title: Group Goal Jar
activity1.achievement: Team effort for a common goal

objective: Review past lessons and build awareness of personal money behavior.
explanation:
• Reflecting helps us learn from what we’ve done.
• We can change habits to become better with money.
• Small steps lead to big results over time.

objective: Understand the role of banks and how they help manage money.
explanation:
• · Banks keep our money safe and help us save.
• · They offer services like savings accounts and loans.
• · We can deposit and withdraw money through banks.

activity2.title: Bank Service Match
materials: Flashcards showing bank services and definitions (e.g.

objective: Learn how interest works when saving money in a bank.
explanation:
• · Interest is extra money banks give us for saving.
• · The more we save and longer we keep it, the more we earn.

objective: Understand different types of investments and risk levels.
explanation:
• · We can invest in stocks, bonds, or real estate.
• · Investments grow over time but carry risk.
• · Some are safer but slower-growing.

objective: Identify different ways people earn income.
explanation:
• · Income is money we earn from work, businesses, or investments.
• · Types: earned, passive, portfolio.

objective: Learn about making choices and what we give up.
explanation:
• · Choosing one thing means giving up another.
• · This is called opportunity cost.
• · Helps us make better decisions.

activity2.title: Story Scenarios
materials: Short story cards with spending choices

objective: Learn to budget for specific occasions.
explanation:
• · Events like birthdays need budgeting.
• · Plan how much to spend on each part.
• · Avoid overspending.

objective: Understand how digital payments work.
explanation:
• · We can shop and pay using apps.
• · Digital money works through cards or accounts.
• · Be careful online.

objective: Learn why people use insurance and how it works.
explanation:
• · Insurance protects against unexpected costs.
• · Pay a little now to avoid big bills later.
• · Many types exist.

activity2.title: Insurance Match Game
materials: Cards with insurance types and examples

objective: Introduction to how credit scores and borrowing work.
explanation:
• · A credit score shows how trustworthy someone is with money.
• · Paying on time builds good credit.

objective: Understand how countries trade and affect each other’s economies.
explanation:
• · Countries trade goods/services.
• · Currencies differ.
• · Economies are connected.

activity2.title: Import/Export Match
materials: Cards with countries and their exports

objective: To understand online banking, mobile apps, and digital transactions.
explanation:
• · Digital banking allows us to manage money using phones or computers.
• · We can check balances, transfer money, and pay bills online.
• · It's important to keep our login info safe.

activity1.title: Banking App Demo
materials: Mock banking app interface (paper or digital)

activity2.title: Login Safety Activity
activity2.achievement: Know how to stay safe online.

objective: To understand how choices impact finances and resources.
explanation:
• · Every choice has a cost, called an opportunity cost.
• · We make economic choices daily, like how to spend time or money.
• · Learning to choose wisely helps us use resources better.

activity1.title: Choice Comparison Chart
materials: Chart with 2 columns (Choice A vs. Choice B)

objective: To introduce the concept of insurance and how it protects us.
explanation:
• · Insurance helps us pay for big problems, like accidents or damage.
• · We pay a small amount regularly (a premium) for protection.
• · It’s a way to share risk and feel secure.

objective: To learn basic principles of supply and demand in markets.
explanation:
• · When many people want something, the price goes up.
• · When there is too much of something, the price may go down.
• · This helps set prices in the economy.

objective: To understand how businesses are built and run.
explanation:
• · Businesses provide goods or services and earn money.
• · They need a plan, team, and good decisions.
• · Being creative and solving problems is key to business success.

objective: To explore what it costs to live in different places.
explanation:
• · Every place has different prices for food, housing, and clothes.
• · Cost of living affects how far our money goes.
• · Budgeting changes based on location.

activity1.title: City Comparison Activity
materials: Item price lists from two cities

objective: To learn how government affects money and the economy.
explanation:
• · Governments collect taxes to provide public services.
• · They also create laws that help keep the economy fair.
• · Sometimes they support businesses or families with help.

objective: To understand how learning and health are financial investments.
explanation:
• · When we learn new skills, we can earn more later.
• · Staying healthy saves money on medical costs.
• · These are called personal investments.

objective: To learn how to plan and predict outcomes in money decisions.
explanation:
• · A decision tree helps map out choices and consequences.
• · It shows what might happen if we choose one path over another.
• · This helps us make smarter money decisions.

objective: To differentiate between earning money and building long-term wealth.
explanation:
• · Income is the money we earn regularly (like allowance or salary).
• · Wealth is what we save, invest, and own.
• · Wealth grows over time, not just through earning.

activity1.title: Income Sources Brainstorm
activity1.achievement: Spot difference between income and assets.

objective: To explore different types of economic systems and how they function.
explanation:
• · Economic systems decide how a country uses its resources.
• · Common systems include capitalism, socialism, and mixed economies.
• · Each system has different ways of handling goods, services, and wealth.

objective: To understand how taxes are collected and used.
explanation:
• · Taxes are collected by the government to fund services.
• · Types include income tax, sales tax, and property tax.
• · Governments must budget how they spend tax money.

objective: To understand how borrowing money works and the role of interest.
explanation:
• · Loans help us buy things now and pay later.
• · Interest is the cost of borrowing money.
• · Higher interest means more to repay over time.

objective: To explore different sources of income and passive income.
explanation:
• · Income can come from work, investments, or side businesses.
• · Passive income is earned with little ongoing effort.
• · More income sources offer stability.

objective: To introduce foreign exchange and currency value changes.
explanation:
• · Currency exchange lets people trade money from one country to another.
• · Exchange rates change based on global factors.
• · Forex is the global market where currencies are traded.

objective: To understand inflation and how it affects what money can buy.
explanation:
• · Inflation makes prices rise over time.
• · This means your money buys less than before.
• · Saving and investing wisely helps fight inflation.

activity1.title: Price Comparison Over Time
materials: Price lists from past and present

objective: To understand different services offered by banks.
explanation:
• · Banks offer savings and checking accounts, loans, and more.
• · They keep money safe and help it grow.
• · Online and in-person services are available.

activity1.title: Bank Tour
materials: Access to virtual tour or branch visit

objective: To teach how to manage finances for a small business.
explanation:
• · A budget includes income, costs, and profit plans.
• · Good budgeting helps avoid losses.
• · Businesses need to plan for savings and surprises.

objective: To break down how a paycheck works and what deductions mean.
explanation:
• · A paycheck shows gross income and net income.
• · Deductions include taxes and benefits.
• · It's important to read and understand your paycheck.

objective: To begin organizing personal finances and investments.
explanation:
• · A portfolio includes savings, investments, and income sources.
• · It shows how your money is growing and where it's going.
• · Diversifying a portfolio reduces risk.

objective: To explore the relationship between risk and reward.
explanation:
• · Higher returns often come with higher risk.
• · Risk tolerance depends on your goals and comfort level.
• · Diversifying investments helps manage risk.

objective: To understand how businesses are created through innovation.
explanation:
• · Entrepreneurs solve problems with new ideas.
• · Innovation can lead to successful businesses.
• · Creativity and planning are key to entrepreneurship.

objective: To learn how credit scores work and why they matter.
explanation:
• · A credit score shows how reliable someone is at repaying loans.
• · Scores are based on payment history, debt levels, and more.
• · A good score helps you borrow at better rates.

objective: To discuss making responsible and fair financial decisions.
explanation:
• · Ethical behavior means being honest and fair with money.
• · Avoiding fraud, respecting contracts, and giving back are ethical choices.
• · Ethical choices build trust in business and personal finance.

objective: To learn about new ways of raising money online.
explanation:
• · Crowdfunding gathers small amounts of money from many people online.
• · It supports business ideas, personal needs, or causes.
• · Platforms like Kickstarter and GoFundMe make this possible.

objective: To explore how countries trade goods and manage money.
explanation:
• · Countries import and export goods to meet needs and grow.
• · Exchange rates affect trade prices.
• · Trade agreements impact economies.

objective: To understand how insurance works and why it’s important.
explanation:
• · Insurance helps cover unexpected financial losses.
• · Types include health, auto, life, and property insurance.
• · People pay premiums for protection against big risks.

objective: To build a detailed personal or family budget.
explanation:
• · Budgeting helps manage income and expenses.
• · Categories include fixed, variable, and discretionary spending.
• · Tracking and adjusting is key to success.

objective: To understand how digital tools are changing money management.
explanation:
• · Fintech includes apps and technology that handle money.
• · Tools like digital wallets and budgeting apps make finance easier.
• · It’s important to use them securely.

objective: To think long-term about money, careers, and life goals.
explanation:
• · Planning ahead includes saving for college, career, and retirement.
• · Setting financial goals gives direction.
• · Small steps today lead to big rewards later.

objective: To understand how inflation affects the value of money.
explanation:
• · Inflation means prices rise over time, reducing purchasing power.
• · Even if income stays the same, inflation makes money buy less.
• · Savings must grow faster than inflation to maintain value.

activity1.title: Price Comparison Over Time
activity1.achievement: Understand how prices rise over time.

objective: To explore how different economies function.
explanation:
• · Economic systems (capitalism, socialism, etc.) manage how resources are distributed.
• · Each system has pros and cons in terms of control, efficiency, and equity.
• · Governments play different roles in each.

activity1.title: Economic System Match
materials: Cards with country names and system descriptions

objective: To learn how borrowing money works and how interest is applied.
explanation:
• · Loans let you borrow money with the promise to repay it, often with interest.
• · Interest is the cost of borrowing.
• · Higher interest rates make loans more expensive.

objective: To explore types of taxes and how they affect income and spending.
explanation:
• · Taxes fund public services like roads, schools, and healthcare.
• · Types include income tax, sales tax, property tax, etc.
• · Tax rates vary by income, location, and type.

activity2.title: Tax Allocation Game
activity2.achievement: Prioritize spending based on community needs.

objective: To understand legal financial agreements and responsibilities.
explanation:
• · A contract is a legal agreement between two or more parties.
• · Financial contracts include leases, loans, and service agreements.
• · Reading and understanding terms is critical.

objective: To understand what central banks do and their role in the economy.
explanation:
• · Central banks manage national monetary policy.
• · They control interest rates and money supply.
• · They aim to keep inflation stable and promote employment.

objective: To plan and possibly launch a real small-scale business.
explanation:
• · A real business requires a plan, capital, budgeting, and marketing.
• · Managing profits and costs is crucial.
• · Entrepreneurship takes persistence and creativity.

topic: Investing in Mutual Funds and ETFs
objective: To explore how people invest through funds and reduce risk.
explanation:
• · Mutual funds and ETFs pool money from investors to buy stocks/bonds.
• · They offer diversification and professional management.
• · They carry fees and risks like all investments.

objective: To understand how emotions and habits influence financial decisions.
explanation:
• · People make financial choices based on fear, excitement, or habits.
• · Knowing your behavior helps avoid impulsive spending.
• · Delayed gratification leads to better long-term outcomes.

activity2.title: Decision Stories
activity2.achievement: Spot the role of emotions in finance.

objective: To learn how wealth grows through planning and consistent action.
explanation:
• · Wealth comes from saving, investing, and managing money wisely.
• · Time, discipline, and smart decisions matter more than luck.
• · Avoiding debt and increasing assets is key.

activity2.title: Financial Life Map
activity2.achievement: Visualize paths to and away from wealth.

objective: Understand how countries interact financially through trade and currency.
explanation:
• · The global economy connects nations via imports, exports, and currency exchange.
• · Exchange rates affect how much things cost internationally.
• · Trade agreements influence jobs and prices.

activity1.title: Trade Simulation
activity1.achievement: Experience of international trade and exchange rates.

objective: Learn how insurance helps manage financial risk.
explanation:
• · Insurance protects against loss (car, health, property).
• · Premiums are paid regularly, and claims provide compensation.
• · Understanding deductibles, coverage, and types is important.

activity1.title: Insurance Match Game
activity1.achievement: Clear grasp of when and why insurance is used.

objective: Explore how income tax works and how it's filed.
explanation:
• · People pay income tax based on earnings.
• · Tax returns report income, deductions, and refunds.
• · Filing taxes is a yearly responsibility.

activity1.title: Tax Form Activity
activity1.achievement: Understand the process of tax filing.

activity2.title: Income Breakdown
activity2.achievement: Realize how taxes affect take-home pay.

objective: Learn how buying, renting, and investing in property works.
explanation:
• · Real estate involves buying, selling, or renting property.
• · Property can increase in value (appreciation).
• · Ownership has responsibilities like taxes and maintenance.

activity1.title: Rent vs. Buy Debate
activity1.achievement: Weigh both sides of a major life decision.

objective: Understand the financial implications of college and alternatives.
explanation:
• · College has costs: tuition, housing, books, etc.
• · Scholarships, loans, and savings (e.g., 529 plans) help pay.
• · Trade schools and apprenticeships are other options.

activity1.title: College Budget
activity1.achievement: Know real costs of higher education.

activity2.title: Path Comparison
materials: Info sheets for various career paths

objective: Explore paycheck components and employee benefits.
explanation:
• · Paychecks show gross pay, deductions, and net pay.
• · Benefits may include health insurance, retirement plans, and bonuses.
• · Understanding pay structure helps evaluate jobs.

activity1.title: Paycheck Decoder
activity1.achievement: Learn how to read a paycheck.

activity2.title: Benefit Comparison
activity2.achievement: Learn to factor in more than salary.

objective: Deepen understanding of how innovation drives business success.
explanation:
• · Entrepreneurship means solving problems in creative ways.
• · Innovation adds value and sets businesses apart.
• · Entrepreneurs take risks for potential rewards.

objective: Learn how financial decisions can align with values.
explanation:
• · Ethical finance includes choosing eco-friendly, fair-trade, or socially responsible investments.
• · Money choices can support causes or avoid harm.
• · Sustainability matters in business and personal finance.

activity1.title: Ethics Sort
materials: Scenario cards with ethical and unethical choices
activity1.achievement: Learn to evaluate money choices ethically.

activity2.title: Research Activity
activity2.achievement: Identify real-world applications of ethical finance.

objective: Understand the evolution of banking with technology.
explanation:
• · Fintech includes digital wallets, online banks, and investment apps.
• · Convenience is high, but cybersecurity is crucial.
• · Staying informed about digital tools is key.

activity2.title: Security Check
activity2.achievement: Know how to protect digital finances.

objective: Plan strategies for growing wealth over decades.
explanation:
• · Wealth building involves saving, investing, and avoiding bad debt.
• · Compound interest and smart investing are crucial.
• · Consistency over time makes a big difference.

activity2.title: Life Planning Map
activity2.achievement: Link money management to life success.

objective: To understand the power of words and how they can express thoughts and feelings.
explanation:
• Words are like magic tools that help us communicate thoughts and feelings.
• We use words to ask for things, share stories, and solve problems.
• Kind words can make others feel good and help us build friendships.

objective: To develop the ability to listen attentively and respond appropriately.
explanation:
• Listening means paying attention when someone else is speaking.
• Good listening helps us understand instructions and stories.
• Listening shows respect and helps us build better friendships.

activity1.title: Whisper Chain
activity1.achievement: Improve focus on words and memory.

objective: To help children recognize and express their emotions healthily.
explanation:
• Everyone has feelings like happy, sad, angry, or scared.
• Talking about our feelings helps others understand us.
• Naming our emotions helps us feel calm and in control.

objective: To understand the importance of non-verbal cues.
explanation:
• We use our face, hands, and body to show how we feel.
• Smiles, frowns, and posture can tell a lot without words.
• Understanding body language helps us know how others feel.

objective: To encourage children to ask questions and seek answers.
explanation:
• Questions help us learn new things and understand the world.
• It’s okay to ask “why,” “how,” and “what” questions.
• Being curious makes learning fun and exciting.

objective: To teach children the importance of taking turns and sharing.
explanation:
• Talking and playing nicely means waiting for your turn.
• Everyone gets a chance to speak and play when we take turns.
• Taking turns helps us build patience and fairness.

objective: To teach children the importance of respecting others.
explanation:
• Respect means being kind and listening to others.
• We show respect by saying “please” and “thank you.”
• Respect helps us make friends and get along with others.

objective: To teach children the power of positive self-talk.
explanation:
• Saying kind things to ourselves helps us feel brave and strong.
• Positive words like “I can do it” encourage us to try.
• Self-talk helps us stay happy even when things are hard.

objective: To teach children how to communicate effectively.
explanation:
• Good communication means using words clearly.
• Listening and asking questions helps others understand us.
• Talking calmly helps solve problems and avoid confusion.

objective: To teach children the importance of empathy and kindness.
explanation:
• Empathy means understanding how someone else feels.
• Kindness means helping and caring for others.
• Being kind and empathetic makes everyone feel loved and safe.

activity1.title: Storytime with Feelings
activity1.achievement: Recognize and talk about emotions of others.

objective: To help children recognize and use different tones of voice.
explanation:
• Tone changes how a message is received.
• A friendly tone makes people feel good.
• A loud or angry tone might make others feel upset.

objective: To teach how to give and follow simple instructions clearly.
explanation:
• Directions help us complete tasks.
• Clear words make directions easier to follow.
• Listening carefully helps understand directions.

objective: To develop basic storytelling and sequencing skills.
explanation:
• Stories have a beginning, middle, and end.
• Using details makes stories more fun.
• Storytelling builds imagination and language.

objective: To encourage open sharing of emotions.
explanation:
• Talking about feelings helps others understand us.
• It’s okay to feel sad, angry, or excited.
• Sharing feelings can build trust.

objective: To teach the value of kind and supportive words.
explanation:
• Kind words can make others feel happy.
• Compliments show we notice good things in others.
• Encouragement helps people try their best.

objective: To reinforce basic politeness in conversation.
explanation:
• Words like “please” and “thank you” show respect.
• Good manners make conversations nicer.
• Being polite helps make friends.

objective: To practice confident introductions.
explanation:
• Saying your name clearly helps others know you.
• Eye contact shows confidence.
• Asking a question can start a friendly conversation.

objective: To improve vocabulary and clarity through descriptive words.
explanation:
• Describing helps others understand what we mean.
• Using size, shape, and color makes it clearer.
• Descriptions are useful for sharing.

objective: To teach how to solve small problems by talking.
explanation:
• Talking helps us solve disagreements peacefully.
• Words like “I feel…” and “Let’s try…” can fix problems.
• Listening helps everyone.

objective: To build honesty and trust in communication.
explanation:
• Telling the truth builds trust.
• Lies can hurt feelings or cause confusion.
• It’s brave to admit mistakes and tell the truth.

objective: To understand how voice tone and volume affect communication.
explanation:
• Voices can be loud, soft, high, or low. 
 • Tone helps show feelings (happy, sad, angry). 
 • Using the right volume is polite and helpful.

objective: To build creative communication and sequencing skills.
explanation:
• Stories have a beginning, middle, and end. 
 • Details help listeners understand. 
 • Telling stories builds memory and confidence.

objective: To encourage positive social interaction.
explanation:
• Compliments make others feel good. 
 • A compliment should be kind and honest. 
 • Builds friendships.

objective: To learn how tone of voice affects meaning.
explanation:
• The same words can sound different depending on tone. 
 • Friendly tones build trust. 
 • Practice helps control tone.

objective: To express feelings through drawing or craft.
explanation:
• Art can be a way to show feelings. 
 • Pictures can “speak” even without words. 
 • Creativity boosts self-expression.

objective: To encourage open conversations about challenges.
explanation:
• Talking about problems helps find solutions. 
 • It’s okay to ask for help. 
 • Expressing feelings makes us feel better.

objective: To improve listening and response skills.
explanation:
• Good communication includes listening well. 
 • Following directions helps in school and play. 
 • Clarifying helps avoid confusion.

objective: To build confidence in seeking assistance.
explanation:
• Asking for help is a smart choice. 
 • Everyone needs help sometimes. 
 • Being polite while asking is important.

objective: To teach respectful communication habits.
explanation:
• Eye contact shows we’re paying attention. 
 • It builds trust and connection. 
 • Practice makes it easier and more natural.

objective: To understand the importance of apologies.
explanation:
• Apologizing shows we care about others’ feelings. 
 • A good apology includes words and meaning. 
 • It helps fix relationships.

objective: To learn how to express opinions kindly.
explanation:
• It's okay to disagree, but we must be kind. 
 • Listening to others builds respect. 
 • Words should never hurt.

objective: To enhance vocabulary and expressive ability.
explanation:
• Descriptive words add detail. 
 • They help paint a picture in the listener’s mind. 
 • They make stories more interesting.

objective: To explore writing as a form of expression.
explanation:
• Writing is a powerful way to share ideas. 
 • It helps organize thoughts clearly. 
 • We can write letters, stories, or messages.

objective: To build confidence in sharing thoughts respectfully.
explanation:
• Everyone’s opinions matter. 
 • We should share thoughts without hurting others. 
 • It’s okay if others think differently.

objective: To practice group communication and cooperation.
explanation:
• Group talks need turn-taking. 
 • Listening to others helps everyone feel included. 
 • Respect builds good teamwork.

objective: To introduce tone and subtle meaning.
explanation:
• Sarcasm says one thing but means another. 
 • Tone and context help us understand it. 
 • It’s tricky but fun to learn.

objective: To teach asking questions when confused.
explanation:
• Clarifying helps avoid mistakes. 
 • Asking is better than guessing. 
 • It shows you care about understanding.

objective: To practice humility and fair participation.
explanation:
• It’s good to let others speak. 
 • Everyone deserves a turn. 
 • Taking over conversations is unkind.

objective: To give helpful, kind suggestions.
explanation:
• Feedback helps us grow. 
 • It should be specific and kind. 
 • Giving and receiving it are both important.

objective: To introduce polite ways to communicate online.
explanation:
• Online talk should be kind and clear. 
 • Emojis help show feelings, but tone matters. 
 • Always ask an adult before chatting.

objective: To improve group communication and listening skills.
explanation:
• Listening helps us understand others and respond thoughtfully. 
 • Group settings require patience and focus. 
 • Listening shows respect.

objective: To teach constructive feedback in a respectful way.
explanation:
• Feedback helps us grow and improve. 
 • Giving feedback respectfully makes it helpful. 
 • Listening to feedback takes courage.

objective: To build confidence and creativity through storytelling.
explanation:
• Storytelling is a way to share thoughts and feelings. 
 • It encourages imagination. 
 • It boosts public speaking.

objective: To understand how tone changes the meaning of words.
explanation:
• Tone expresses emotions. 
 • The same words can mean different things depending on tone. 
 • Tone helps avoid misunderstandings.

objective: To recognize and interpret sarcastic language.
explanation:
• Sarcasm uses tone and context to mean the opposite. 
 • Not everyone understands sarcasm easily. 
 • It can be confusing without cues.

objective: To learn peaceful and respectful conflict resolution.
explanation:
• Conflicts are part of life. 
 • Talking and listening can solve many problems. 
 • Being calm helps resolution.

objective: To develop communication skills that foster friendships.
explanation:
• Friends support and respect each other. 
 • Communication helps deepen bonds. 
 • Kindness builds trust.

objective: To introduce public speaking with confidence.
explanation:
• Speaking clearly helps others understand you. 
 • Eye contact and posture matter. 
 • Practice builds confidence.

objective: To explore humor and timing in communication.
explanation:
• Jokes rely on wordplay, timing, and tone. 
 • Not all jokes are kind. 
 • Humor can build friendships.

objective: To practice respectful disagreement.
explanation:
• Everyone has different views. 
 • Respecting others’ opinions shows maturity. 
 • We can disagree kindly.

objective: To learn how tone is conveyed in messages and texts.
explanation:
• Online messages lack body language. 
 • Tone must be shown with punctuation or emojis. 
 • Misunderstandings can happen easily.

objective: To learn how to form a logical argument.
explanation:
• Good arguments are clear and respectful. 
 • They include reasons and examples. 
 • It's okay to disagree.

objective: To develop persuasive speaking skills.
explanation:
• Persuasion uses emotion and logic. 
 • Tone, posture, and clarity matter. 
 • Being convincing isn’t being pushy.

objective: To teach children how to begin conversations.
explanation:
• Starting conversations shows confidence. 
 • Questions are a great way to start. 
 • It's okay to be nervous.

objective: To practice communication in digital spaces.
explanation:
• Online chats require clarity. 
 • Be kind and clear in texts or comments. 
 • Emojis help, but aren’t always enough.

objective: To understand how to apologize sincerely.
explanation:
• A good apology shows we care. 
 • Saying “I’m sorry” isn’t always enough. 
 • We should also change our behavior.

objective: To express personal views clearly and kindly.
explanation:
• Speaking your mind helps people understand you. 
 • It’s okay to have a different opinion. 
 • Being kind matters more than being right.

objective: To improve focus and listening through following steps.
explanation:
• Instructions help us complete tasks. 
 • Listening carefully is key. 
 • Asking questions can clarify things.

objective: To understand body language and tone in social settings.
explanation:
• Social cues help us know how someone feels. 
 • Facial expressions, gestures, and voice give clues. 
 • Noticing helps us respond better.

objective: To practice offering support through words.
explanation:
• Encouragement helps others feel good. 
 • Kind words build confidence. 
 • Being encouraging shows empathy.

objective: To help children understand and appreciate different points of view.
explanation:
• Everyone sees the world in their own way. 
 • Understanding others helps build empathy. 
 • Listening helps us learn about perspectives.

objective: To introduce the concept of respectful disagreement.
explanation:
• It's okay to have different opinions. 
 • Debates help us learn to listen and respond thoughtfully. 
 • Respect is key during disagreement.

objective: To teach how to give helpful feedback without hurting feelings.
explanation:
• Feedback helps people grow. 
 • Kind words can still be honest. 
 • “I” statements feel less harsh than “you” statements.

objective: To help children notice how tone affects meaning.
explanation:
• The same words can feel different based on tone. 
 • Tone includes pitch, volume, and feeling. 
 • Misunderstandings can happen.

objective: To introduce safe and respectful online interactions.
explanation:
• Online words still have impact. 
 • Think before you send. 
 • Be kind and protect personal info.

objective: To teach how to structure a compelling story.
explanation:
• Stories have a beginning, middle, and end. 
 • Details make stories interesting. 
 • Clear order keeps listeners engaged.

objective: To practice asking thoughtful questions and listening actively.
explanation:
• Interviews help us learn about people. 
 • Good questions are open-ended. 
 • Listening is just as important as asking.

objective: To explore the role of humor in communication and friendships.
explanation:
• Humor can bring people together. 
 • Jokes should never hurt others. 
 • Know when humor is appropriate.

objective: To identify subtle body language signals in communication.
explanation:
• Body language shows emotion. 
 • Eye contact, posture, and gestures all send messages. 
 • Noticing cues helps us respond better.

objective: To learn healthy ways to solve problems with others.
explanation:
• Conflict is normal. 
 • Stay calm and listen. 
 • Use “I” statements and find solutions together.

objective: To teach kids how to adjust their communication based on who they're speaking to.
explanation:
• We speak differently to friends, teachers, and family. 
• Knowing your audience helps make your message clear. 
• Respectful tone is important.

activity1.title: Audience Swap
activity1.achievement: Understand how audience impacts tone and word choice.

objective: To build confidence in speaking clearly in front of a group.
explanation:
• Speaking in front of others helps share ideas. 
• Preparation reduces nervousness. 
• Eye contact and pacing help keep listeners engaged.

objective: To teach how to ask questions and confirm understanding in conversations.
explanation:
• Asking clarifying questions avoids confusion. 
• Confirming what you heard shows respect. 
• It’s okay to ask for repetition or examples.

objective: To develop teamwork and respectful group participation.
explanation:
• Speaking and listening in a group is a skill. 
• Wait turns and avoid interrupting. 
• Everyone's ideas should be heard.

objective: To begin recognizing bias and opinion in news and content.
explanation:
• Media sometimes shows one side of a story. 
• It's important to ask questions and think critically. 
• Not everything online is accurate.

activity1.title: Spot the Bias
materials: Two versions of the same story

objective: To teach how and why to give genuine apologies.
explanation:
• Apologies show we care about others' feelings. 
• A sincere apology includes admitting mistakes. 
• Saying “sorry” can help rebuild trust.

objective: To introduce techniques for speaking persuasively and respectfully.
explanation:
• Persuasive speech can influence opinions. 
• Use strong reasons and examples. 
• Stay respectful even when trying to convince someone.

objective: To learn how visuals enhance communication.
explanation:
• Pictures, charts, and props support messages. 
• Visuals should be clear and helpful. 
• They help explain complex ideas easily.

objective: To practice giving step-by-step instructions others can follow.
explanation:
• Clear instructions avoid confusion. 
• Use sequence words like “first,” “then,” “next.” 
• Check if the other person understood.

objective: To learn how to accept constructive criticism without feeling upset.
explanation:
• Feedback helps us grow. 
• Stay calm and listen fully. 
• Ask questions if you don’t understand.

objective: To teach strategies for resolving disagreements constructively.
explanation:
• Conflicts are normal and can be solved peacefully. 
• Listening and empathy are key to resolving issues. 
• Compromise can help everyone win.

objective: To develop the skill of convincing others respectfully.
explanation:
• Persuasion involves using facts and emotion. 
• Respect for others’ views is important. 
• A strong voice and structure help influence.

objective: To understand how tone impacts messages.
explanation:
• The way something is said affects how it's received. 
• Tone can change the meaning of words. 
• Being aware of tone helps avoid misunderstandings.

objective: To practice participating effectively in group conversations.
explanation:
• Everyone’s voice matters in a discussion. 
• Listening builds group understanding. 
• Staying on topic helps focus.

activity1.title: Circle Chat
activity1.achievement: Practice taking turns and active listening.

objective: To understand how to communicate respectfully online.
explanation:
• Online messages lack tone and body language. 
• Kindness and clarity are crucial online. 
• Think before posting or texting.

activity1.title: Emoji Decode
materials: Printed messages with and without emojis
activity1.achievement: Understand how tone can be altered online.

objective: To learn how to provide and accept feedback constructively.
explanation:
• Feedback helps us grow. 
• It should be kind, specific, and helpful. 
• Accepting feedback calmly shows maturity.

objective: To build confidence in speaking to a group.
explanation:
• Preparation reduces fear. 
• Speaking clearly and slowly helps listeners. 
• Body language supports your message.

objective: To recognize and appropriately respond to sarcasm.
explanation:
• Sarcasm uses tone to mean the opposite. 
• It can be funny or hurtful depending on use. 
• Understanding context is key.

objective: To learn how to make a meaningful apology.
explanation:
• Apologies should be honest and not forced. 
• Taking responsibility matters. 
• Apologies help heal relationships.

objective: To help children express and respect boundaries.
explanation:
• Everyone has personal limits. 
• It's okay to say “no” kindly. 
• Respecting others' boundaries is just as important.

objective: To understand how body language affects conflict situations.
explanation:
• Body language can escalate or de-escalate conflict. 
 • Facial expressions, posture, and eye contact send strong messages. 
 • Calm gestures show readiness to resolve.

activity1.title: Mirror Practice
activity1.achievement: Students become aware of how emotions are communicated nonverbally.

activity2.title: Conflict Freeze Frame
activity2.achievement: Students understand how nonverbal cues escalate or de-escalate conflict.

objective: To explore how people communicate differently across cultures.
explanation:
• Cultures vary in how they use gestures, tone, and eye contact. 
 • Understanding differences prevents miscommunication. 
 • Respect for all styles is important.

activity1.title: Culture Match-Up
materials: Flashcards of gestures and matching cultural norms
activity1.achievement: Recognize cultural variations in nonverbal communication.

objective: To learn how to say no and stand up for personal values.
explanation:
• Peer pressure can be subtle or direct. 
 • Assertive communication helps resist pressure. 
 • Saying no can be done respectfully.

activity1.title: No Practice Drill
activity1.achievement: Develop tools to resist pressure respectfully.

activity2.title: Story Rewrite
materials: Short story or comic strip showing someone giving in to pressure
activity2.achievement: Explore alternative choices in tough social situations.

objective: To use emotional awareness in conversations.
explanation:
• Recognizing emotions helps with empathy. 
 • Speaking with emotion can build stronger messages. 
 • Emotional balance supports healthy dialogue.

activity1.title: Emotion Matching
materials: Phrase cards with various emotional expressions

activity2.title: Talk Back Game
activity2.achievement: Practice using tone to communicate feelings.

objective: To learn how to participate effectively in a team.
explanation:
• Every group has different personalities. 
 • Communication roles (leader, mediator, listener) matter. 
 • Respect and cooperation are key.

activity1.title: Role Assignment Game
activity1.achievement: Learn how roles affect group success.

activity2.title: Team Reflection
activity2.achievement: Reflect on group work and roles.

objective: To spot and respond to manipulative language.
explanation:
• Manipulation uses guilt, pressure, or flattery. 
 • It often benefits one side unfairly. 
 • Calm refusal and questions can stop it.

activity1.title: Spot the Trick
materials: Statement cards with honest and manipulative phrases

objective: To share ideas without offending others.
explanation:
• Strong opinions can be shared kindly. 
 • Language choice makes a big difference. 
 • Respecting different views builds trust.

objective: To reflect on how media changes the way we talk and think.
explanation:
• Social media can shape communication habits. 
 • Algorithms can influence what we see and share. 
 • Critical thinking is essential online.

activity1.title: Ad Decoder
materials: Screenshots or printouts of social media posts

objective: To practice showing appreciation verbally and non-verbally.
explanation:
• Gratitude strengthens relationships. 
 • It can be shown through words, actions, or gestures. 
 • Regular appreciation creates a positive environment.

objective: To explore how humor can help or hurt in social situations.
explanation:
• Humor can build connection, relieve tension, or cause harm. 
 • Understanding timing and audience is key. 
 • Not all jokes are kind.

activity1.title: Joke Analyzer
activity1.achievement: Learn the impact of different types of humor.

activity2.title: Rewrite Challenge
activity2.achievement: Show that humor can be positive.

objective: To introduce the idea of robots and what they can do.
explanation:
• Robots are machines that can do tasks. 
 • Some look like humans, others like cars or animals. 
 • They help people by doing work.

activity1.title: Robot Toy Sorting
steps: Mix the toys together.
Ask child to find only the robots.
Talk about what makes them different.

activity2.title: Move Like a Robot Game
steps: You act like a robot with stiff arms.
Ask child to copy your moves.
Give simple commands: turn, pick, walk.

objective: To understand how AI helps at home.
explanation:
• Some machines can be smart helpers like Alexa or Siri. 
 • They listen and answer questions. 
 • They make life easier.

activity1.title: Guess the Helper Sound
steps: Play sounds (like Alexa alarm or Siri voice).
Ask child to guess what it is.
Talk about how we use it.

activity2.title: Helper Matching Game
steps: Show real-life situation (like cleaning).
Ask child to match it with the right AI helper.

objective: To explore how machines understand voice.
explanation:
• Some machines understand when we speak. 
 • They can follow simple voice commands. 
 • This is called voice recognition.

activity1.title: Command the Toy
steps: Show card with action like “Jump” or “Turn.”
Say the word to the toy.
Pretend it listens and does it.

activity2.title: Simon Says with a Twist
steps: Play Simon Says, but say you’re a robot.
Give voice commands like “Simon says wave.”
Sometimes don’t say “Simon says.”

objective: To introduce how some machines can see using cameras.
explanation:
• Some machines have cameras like eyes. 
 • They can look at things and understand them. 
 • This is called computer vision.

activity1.title: Find the Object
steps: Show picture card of an object (like a ball).
Ask child to “scan” the room with toy camera to find it.
Talk about how machines do the same.

activity2.title: Camera or Not?
steps: Show toys and ask if it has a “camera.”
Talk about what a machine needs to see.

objective: To help children see how machines learn from patterns.
explanation:
• AI learns by looking at patterns. 
 • It can find what comes next. 
 • Just like we do in games and puzzles.

activity1.title: Shape Pattern Game
steps: Make a simple pattern (red, blue, red, blue).
Ask child what comes next.
Let them make their own.

activity2.title: Finish the Row
steps: Show pattern with missing piece.
Ask child to fill it.

objective: To understand how machines sort things into groups.
explanation:
• AI can group things by color, size, or shape. 
 • It helps organize and find things quickly. 
 • This is called classification.

activity1.title: Toy Sorting Time
steps: Ask child to sort toys by color, then shape.
Talk about how machines do the same.

activity2.title: Food or Not?
materials: Toy food items and non-food toys.
steps: Mix toys and ask child to find only food.
Let them explain why.

objective: To explore how machines can listen and understand sound.
explanation:
• Some AI tools can hear sounds. 
 • They recognize words and noises. 
 • This is how voice assistants work.

activity1.title: Clap Pattern Game
steps: Clap a pattern (e.g., clap clap pause).
Ask child to repeat it.
Explain how machines also listen to sound patterns.

activity2.title: Sound Sorting
steps: Play each sound.
Ask child to name the sound type.

objective: To introduce how some toys use AI to respond.
explanation:
• Some toys can talk, sing, or move. 
 • They have sensors and AI inside. 
 • They can react to what we do.

activity1.title: Meet My Smart Toy
steps: Show toy’s features (talking, blinking).
Ask child to explore and describe it.

activity2.title: Pretend to Be Smart Toy
steps: Child pretends to be a smart toy.
You give commands, they respond like the toy.

objective: To explore how robots can act like friends or helpers.
explanation:
• Some robots can talk, dance, or play. 
 • They can feel like friendly companions. 
 • People use them for fun or help.

activity1.title: Robot Dance Time
steps: Play music and do robot dance moves.
Let child copy and create moves.

activity2.title: Talk to the Robot
steps: Have a pretend chat with the robot.
Ask child to tell it something.

objective: To understand how AI helps people learn new things.
explanation:
• AI can help us read, count, and play learning games. 
 • It gives feedback and teaches. 
 • Like a helper teacher.

activity1.title: AI Learning App Time
steps: Let child try or watch learning app.
Ask what it teaches.

activity2.title: Teach the Robot
steps: Ask child to teach ABC or 123 to robot.
Pretend robot repeats it.

objective: To explore how AI can talk or reply to people.
explanation:
• Some machines can reply when we talk. 
 • They use AI to understand and answer. 
 • Like voice assistants and chatbots.

activity1.title: Hello Machine
materials: Phone or toy with voice assistant.
steps: Say “Hello” and wait for reply.
Try other simple phrases.

activity2.title: Echo Game
steps: You say something, child repeats like a robot.
Swap roles.

objective: To recognize AI characters in shows.
explanation:
• Some cartoons have robots or smart characters. 
 • They show how AI helps or thinks. 
 • Kids can connect real AI with stories.

activity1.title: Find the AI Friend
steps: Watch and pause when robot or AI comes.
Talk about what it does.

activity2.title: Draw the AI Character
steps: Ask child to draw their favorite smart cartoon character.
Talk about what makes it smart.

objective: To identify AI helpers used at home.
explanation:
• AI can be used in vacuums, lights, speakers. 
 • It helps make things easier. 
 • Kids learn how homes can be smart.

activity1.title: Spot the Smart Tool
steps: Walk around and find smart things (e.g. Alexa, robot vacuum).
Ask what it does.

activity2.title: Make a Smart Room
steps: Let child build or draw a room with AI helpers.
Ask what each tool does.

objective: To understand how AI sees pictures and spots things.
explanation:
• AI can look at photos and say what’s in them. 
 • It detects people, animals, or objects. 
 • This is used in cameras and apps.

activity1.title: What’s in the Picture?
steps: Show pictures and ask child to say what they see.
Talk about how AI does this too.

activity2.title: Camera Scan Game
steps: Ask child to scan a toy, pretend it tells what it is.
Take turns.

objective: To show how AI makes games smarter and fun.
explanation:
• Many games use AI to challenge or help. 
 • AI can learn how we play. 
 • It makes games more exciting.

activity1.title: Play with a Smart Game
materials: Simple digital game or toy with AI.
steps: Play together and see how it responds.
Ask child what they notice.

activity2.title: Make Your Own Game
steps: Create a simple pretend AI game.
Use rules that respond to child’s action.

objective: To explore how AI can create or play music.
explanation:
• Some machines can make music. 
 • AI can suggest songs or play instruments. 
 • Kids can see AI as creative.

activity1.title: AI Music Time
steps: Let child explore songs recommended by app.
Ask what they liked.

activity2.title: Make AI Sounds
steps: Pretend to be an AI composer.
Child creates a beat or tune.

objective: To help kids see how AI might respond to emotions.
explanation:
• AI can sometimes understand if we’re happy or sad. 
 • It helps robots or apps react. 
 • Not all AI can do this yet.

activity1.title: Emotion Face Match
steps: Show a face, ask child to name the feeling.
Pretend AI is learning it.

activity2.title: How Should AI Feel?
steps: Describe a scene (happy birthday), ask child how AI might react.
Try different emotions.

objective: To understand how AI uses both seeing and hearing.
explanation:
• AI can use cameras and microphones. 
 • It sees and hears to learn better. 
 • Kids relate this to their own senses.

activity1.title: I Spy and Hear
steps: Play “I spy” and then “I hear” games.
Relate to AI using both.

activity2.title: What Did You See and Hear?
steps: Watch and ask child what they saw and heard.
Talk about how AI would learn from it.

objective: To show how AI helps us stay safe.
explanation:
• AI is used in alarms, cameras, and alerts. 
 • It helps protect people. 
 • Children learn safety uses.

activity1.title: Spot the Safety Helper
steps: Look for smart alarms or cameras.
Ask what they do.

activity2.title: Make a Safety Poster
steps: Draw how AI keeps us safe.
Label tools like “smart alarm” or “camera.”

objective: To let kids imagine a world filled with AI.
explanation:
• Kids build stories or places where AI helps. 
 • It builds imagination with tech. 
 • Helps them see possibilities.

activity1.title: Build an AI Town
steps: Create a town with AI buses, helpers, etc.
Ask what each one does.

activity2.title: My Day with AI
steps: Ask child to describe a day with AI friends.
Act or draw it out.

objective: To see how AI helps animals and wildlife.
explanation:
• AI is used to track animals and protect them. 
 • It helps in zoos, farms, and forests. 
 • Kids connect AI with nature.

activity1.title: Track the Tiger
steps: Pretend you’re tracking a tiger using AI.
Mark areas on a paper map.

activity2.title: Zoo Watch
steps: Watch animals and talk about how AI could help feed, track, or clean.

objective: To explore how robots clean using AI.
explanation:
• Cleaning robots use AI to move and avoid things. 
 • They help at home or big buildings. 
 • Kids see robots working.

activity1.title: Robot Mop Game
materials: Toy robot or a cloth and toy.
steps: Let child pretend to be a robot cleaning.
Avoid obstacles like chairs or boxes.

activity2.title: Watch It Clean
steps: Observe how it moves and avoids things.
Discuss how it “thinks.”

objective: To understand that AI can create art too.
explanation:
• AI can draw, paint, and design. 
 • It learns from styles and makes new ones. 
 • AI can be creative too.

activity1.title: Create Like AI
steps: Ask child to copy a simple style (e.g. dots, lines).
Then mix styles to create their own.

activity2.title: AI vs Me
materials: Online AI art tool and paper.
steps: Generate an image using a tool.
Child makes a similar one. Compare!

objective: To see how AI helps predict weather.
explanation:
• AI looks at past weather and predicts future. 
 • It helps plan for rain or sun. 
 • Weather apps use AI.

activity1.title: Predict the Weather
steps: Look at weather for a week.
Guess tomorrow’s forecast.

activity2.title: Dress for the Day
steps: Based on the forecast, dress up a doll or toy.
Talk about the AI prediction.

objective: To explore how AI controls traffic and lights.
explanation:
• AI helps in traffic lights, cameras, and planning roads. 
 • It reduces jams and keeps people safe. 
 • Kids see how movement is managed.

activity1.title: Traffic Light Game
steps: Play a walking game where AI gives light commands.
Stop, slow, go!

activity2.title: City Planner
steps: Build a city road setup.
Plan where smart lights should go.

objective: To learn how AI turns voice into words.
explanation:
• AI listens and writes what we say. 
 • Used in phones and computers. 
 • It helps typing and messages.

activity1.title: Speak and See
steps: Speak and watch the words appear.
Try new phrases.

activity2.title: Dictation Partner
steps: One speaks, the other writes. Swap roles.
Discuss how AI does it too.

objective: To show how AI helps learn new languages.
explanation:
• AI apps can teach new words and sounds. 
 • They listen and correct. 
 • It helps kids speak better.

activity1.title: Try a Word App
steps: Use app for basic words.
Repeat and score.

activity2.title: Say It in Another Way
steps: Show picture and say word in English.
AI or adult says it in another language.

objective: To explore how AI helps farmers.
explanation:
• AI machines water, harvest, and check plants. 
 • Used in big farms to grow more food. 
 • Kids relate tech to nature.

activity1.title: Plant Watcher
steps: Pretend to be an AI robot checking plants.
Report dry, tall, or sick ones.

activity2.title: Robot Farmer
steps: Act like a robot doing farm tasks.
Water, pluck, measure.

objective: To show how AI helps in space.
explanation:
• Satellites and rovers use AI to work far away. 
 • They send info and avoid danger. 
 • Helps scientists explore.

activity1.title: Rover Explorer
steps: Pretend to explore another planet.
Avoid rocks and find samples.

activity2.title: What AI Sees
steps: Look at images and guess what AI sees.
Talk about Earth shapes.

objective: To explore how AI helps in games and fitness.
explanation:
• AI tracks movement and suggests improvements. 
 • Used in sports training. 
 • It makes play smarter.

activity1.title: Coach AI
steps: Play and give feedback like an AI coach.
“Try faster,” “Turn left,” etc.

activity2.title: Track Me!
steps: Record how fast child runs 3 times.
Pretend AI tracks and gives score.

objective: To understand how AI solves puzzles and paths.
explanation:
• AI finds the best way through a maze. 
• It tries different paths. 
• It remembers what works.

activity1.title: Maze Navigator
steps: Give a simple maze to the child.
Let them find the path.
Discuss how AI tries many paths.

activity2.title: Smart Path Game
steps: Set up a path with dead ends.
Ask child to guide toy to finish.
Help with hints like AI.

objective: To introduce how AI talks and helps people.
explanation:
• AI chatbots answer questions. 
• They use words to understand us. 
• Help in stores and websites.

activity1.title: Chatbot Role Play
steps: Pretend to be a chatbot.
Answer simple questions.
Use polite words.

activity2.title: Ask Me Anything
steps: Ask child easy questions.
Child answers like a chatbot.

objective: To explore how AI can create art.
explanation:
• AI makes drawings and music. 
• It learns from patterns. 
• Helps in creative work.

activity1.title: Drawing Robot
steps: Draw simple shapes.
Pretend the robot chooses colors.

activity2.title: Music Maker
steps: Make beats together.
Pretend AI mixes sounds.

objective: To learn how AI helps in telling stories.
explanation:
• AI can create stories with ideas. 
• It mixes words and pictures. 
• Helps people write books.

activity1.title: Story Building
steps: Pick cards to make a story.
Tell story like AI would.

activity2.title: Picture Story
steps: Draw parts of a story.
Explain story like AI.

objective: To show how AI finds clues and solves mysteries.
explanation:
• AI uses clues to find answers. 
• It looks for patterns in data. 
• Helps solve problems.

activity1.title: Clue Hunt
steps: Hide objects and find clues.
Pretend to be AI detectives.

activity2.title: Pattern Match
steps: Find matching cards.
Explain how AI finds matches.

objective: To understand how AI predicts weather.
explanation:
• AI watches clouds and wind. 
• It guesses if it will rain or shine. 
• Helps plan days better.

activity1.title: Weather Watch
steps: Observe weather daily.
Predict tomorrow’s weather.
Compare with actual.

activity2.title: Cloud Detectives
steps: Identify cloud types.
Learn what they mean.

objective: To explore how AI helps animals and nature.
explanation:
• AI tracks animals to keep them safe. 
• It studies how animals live. 
• Helps protect wildlife.

activity1.title: Animal Tracker
steps: Identify animals in pictures.
Talk about AI helping track.

activity2.title: Nature Walk
steps: Walk outside to observe animals.
Record what is seen.

objective: To imagine how AI can help learn about the past.
explanation:
• AI studies old pictures and data. 
• It helps understand history. 
• Makes learning fun.

activity1.title: History Puzzle
steps: Look at old pictures.
Talk about what they show.
Pretend AI helps explain.

activity2.title: Timeline Game
steps: Put events in order.
Explain with AI’s help.

objective: To learn how AI helps explore space.
explanation:
• AI controls rovers and satellites. 
• It sends back information. 
• Helps scientists learn more.

activity1.title: Rover Explorer
steps: Pretend to explore another planet.
Avoid obstacles and find samples.

activity2.title: What AI Sees
steps: Look at images and guess what AI sees.
Talk about Earth shapes.

objective: To explore how AI solves complex puzzles.
explanation:
• AI tries many moves to solve puzzles. 
• It learns from mistakes. 
• Helps in games and research.

activity1.title: Puzzle Solver
steps: Try to solve puzzles step-by-step.
Talk about AI trying again if stuck.

activity2.title: Move It Right
steps: Play a simple game.
Think about best moves like AI.

objective: To help children see how AI finds patterns in things.
explanation:
• AI looks for patterns in colors, sounds, or actions. 
 • These patterns help it learn and guess what comes next. 
 • It’s like solving puzzles!

activity1.title: Pattern Detective
steps: Make a color pattern like red-blue-red-blue.
Ask the child to continue it.
Try new patterns: size, shape, or number.

activity2.title: What Comes Next?
steps: Show shape pattern cards.
Child guesses the next shape.
Explain how AI guesses using patterns.

objective: To explore how AI understands sounds and words.
explanation:
• AI listens to voices and sounds. 
 • It turns sound into text or action. 
 • Voice assistants use this skill.

activity1.title: Echo Game
steps: Say a sentence clearly.
Child repeats like an AI.
Talk about how AI “hears” to repeat.

activity2.title: Sound Sorter
steps: Play or make animal and object sounds.
Ask the child to group them.
Talk about how AI knows differences.

objective: To show how AI creates pictures using ideas.
explanation:
• AI can draw from words or parts of images. 
 • It learns styles and adds details. 
 • It imagines like an artist!

activity1.title: Style Mix-Up
steps: Show different art styles.
Ask child to mix them in one drawing.
Compare how AI blends styles.

activity2.title: Word to Picture
steps: Say a funny combo.
Child draws it.
Discuss how AI turns words into images.

topic: AI and the Magic of Sorting
objective: To teach how AI groups similar things together.
explanation:
• AI learns by sorting objects by features. 
 • It can group by color, shape, sound, or more. 
 • Helps in organizing big data.

activity1.title: Shape Cluster
steps: Spread blocks randomly.
Child sorts into groups.
Compare to AI sorting data.

activity2.title: Odd One Out
steps: Show 3 similar, 1 odd item.
Ask child to spot the odd one.
Talk about how AI learns this.

objective: To introduce the idea of how AI stores and recalls data.
explanation:
• AI keeps memories in its system. 
 • It uses past data to make decisions. 
 • This helps it learn over time.

activity1.title: Memory Match
steps: Flip cards and find pairs.
Relate this to how AI remembers.
Ask child how remembering helps decisions.

activity2.title: Recall Robot
steps: Show 5 items for 10 seconds.
Hide and ask child to recall.
Compare with how AI saves info.

objective: To explore how chatbots talk with people.
explanation:
• AI can answer questions like a human. 
 • It uses words it learned from reading. 
 • Used in phones and websites.

activity1.title: Build a Bot Chat
steps: Child creates a paper chatbot face.
You ask questions; they reply like a bot.
Discuss how bots think before replying.

activity2.title: Right Reply
steps: Show a question.
Give 3 reply choices.
Ask child to choose best answer.

objective: To introduce the idea of emotional AI.
explanation:
• Some AIs try to read emotions. 
 • They look at faces, voices, and words. 
 • It helps them act kindly.

activity1.title: Face Feelings
steps: Show happy, sad, angry faces.
Ask child to guess the feeling.
Talk about how AI guesses emotions.

activity2.title: Voice Mood
steps: Say “I’m fine” in happy/sad/angry tone.
Ask child to guess mood.
Link to how AI hears feelings.

objective: To explain how AI makes true/false choices.
explanation:
• AI often answers yes/no or true/false. 
 • It uses logic rules to decide. 
 • Like flipping switches in its brain.

activity1.title: Logic Switch
steps: Ask simple questions: “Is sky blue?”
Child answers yes or no.
Explain how AI decides similarly.

activity2.title: If-Then Fun
steps: Write “If I clap, then you jump.”
Try different if-then combos.
Explain AI also uses such rules.

objective: To show how AI learns by training.
explanation:
• AI doesn’t know things at first. 
 • We teach it using examples. 
 • The more we teach, the better it gets.

activity1.title: Picture Trainer
steps: Show 3 cat photos, 3 dogs.
Ask child to teach AI to tell them apart.
Use “This is a cat” etc.

activity2.title: AI Learns Names
steps: Say each person’s name with a photo.
Ask AI (you) to recall.
Talk about how AI improves.

objective: To explore how AI creates new things from ideas.
explanation:
• AI can write poems, stories, or make songs. 
 • It mixes learning with creativity. 
 • Like a digital imagination.

activity1.title: Story Starter
steps: Pick 3 cards: “Forest,” “Robot,” “Pizza.”
Child makes a story.
Say AI does the same with words.

activity2.title: Music Maker
steps: Make a beat pattern.
Ask child to add a twist.
Discuss how AI composes like this.

objective: To understand how AI learns from errors.
explanation:
• AI makes guesses and checks if it’s right. 
 • When wrong, it tries again differently.
