 • This is how it gets smarter.

activity1.title: Learning Loops
steps: Write 3 simple math problems.
Solve once, check, and retry mistakes.
Talk about how retrying helps.

activity2.title: AI Retry Race
steps: Try solving puzzle in time.
If wrong, adjust and retry faster.

objective: To introduce how AI detects patterns.
explanation:
• AI looks at data to find regular things. 
 • Patterns help AI predict. 
 • Used in games, weather, and more.

activity1.title: Pattern Finder
steps: Create color patterns with beads.
Ask child to continue or fix broken pattern.

activity2.title: Prediction Time
steps: Look at 5 days’ data.
Ask what tomorrow might be.

objective: To explore how AI can detect emotions.
explanation:
• AI reads faces, voices, and words. 
 • It guesses if someone is happy or sad. 
 • Used in games and support bots.

activity1.title: Mood Mirror
steps: Make happy, sad, surprised faces.
Guess what AI would say.

activity2.title: Voice Detective
steps: Say same sentence in 3 tones.
Guess emotion behind voice.

objective: To understand step-by-step thinking.
explanation:
• AI follows rules in steps. 
 • Just like giving a robot clear orders. 
 • No guesswork, only logic.

activity1.title: Order Me!
steps: Ask child to guide you to a chair step-by-step.
Follow exactly.
Show what happens with wrong steps.

activity2.title: Code My Walk
steps: Make a grid path.
Use forward/right/left commands.

objective: To learn what a neural network is.
explanation:
• Neural networks are like a web of smart nodes. 
 • They work like tiny brains inside AI. 
 • They help AI learn.

activity1.title: Web of Thinking
steps: Create a web with yarn across pins.
Show how signals travel.

activity2.title: Node Game
steps: Each person is a node.
Pass messages with decisions.

objective: To imagine AI learning from history.
explanation:
• AI reads old data to understand the past. 
 • It helps predict future events. 
 • Used in studies and museums.

activity1.title: Time Capsule Scan
steps: Explore old objects or stories.
Guess what AI might learn.

activity2.title: Future Guess
steps: Based on old trends, guess future tech.
Record and draw ideas.

objective: To explore animal behavior recognition.
explanation:
• AI watches animals to learn patterns. 
 • It tracks how they move and live. 
 • Used in wildlife protection.

activity1.title: Track the Tiger
steps: Place footprints around home.
Follow path like AI tracker.

activity2.title: Who’s Who in the Wild
steps: Show different animals.
Guess what AI might learn from them.

objective: To show how AI mimics behavior.
explanation:
• AI can watch and copy human actions. 
 • Like how kids copy adults. 
 • Used in robots and training.

activity1.title: Mirror Me
steps: Stand in front of child.
Do actions slowly.
Ask child to copy exactly.

activity2.title: AI Copy Bot
steps: Do task once.
Child pretends to be AI and repeats.

objective: To discover how AI creates art and stories.
explanation:
• AI can draw, write, or compose music. 
 • It uses data and learns style. 
 • Combines logic with creativity.

activity1.title: AI Artist
steps: Draw random shapes.
Create a story or art around it like AI might.

activity2.title: Smart Story Builder
steps: Pick 3 cards.
Build a story like AI would.

objective: To begin basic coding concepts through AI.
explanation:
• AI uses code to function. 
 • Code gives it rules to follow. 
 • Kids can start learning code too.

activity1.title: Code My Robot
steps: Set up a map.
Use arrows to “code” movement to target.

activity2.title: Code Dance
steps: Create dance steps as code.
Perform as per written code.

objective: To explore how AI creates art, music, and stories.
explanation:
• AI can be trained to create drawings, poems, or songs.
• It uses patterns it has learned from humans.
• It doesn't feel, but it can surprise us with ideas.

activity1.title: ImagineBot
steps: Ask child to draw or write like an AI trying to imagine something new.
Compare with a real AI-generated image or poem.

activity2.title: Inspiration or Copy?
materials: Printouts of real vs AI art or stories.
steps: Show examples and ask child to guess if AI or human made it.
Discuss what clues helped them decide.

topic: The AI That Learns From You
objective: To understand machine learning through feedback loops.
explanation:
• AI improves when it gets feedback.
• Just like a student, it learns from mistakes.
• You help it get smarter with your input.

activity1.title: Teach the Robot
materials: Friend or adult acting like a robot.
steps: Give a task and correct mistakes as they act.
Repeat until it’s perfect.

activity2.title: Spot the Pattern
steps: Show series of shapes, colors, or numbers.
Ask what comes next and why.

objective: To explore how AI stores and recalls data.
explanation:
• AI uses data to make decisions.
• It stores memory differently from humans.
• More data often means better predictions.

activity1.title: Memory Sorter
steps: Show items to “train” memory.
Ask the child to sort or recall based on pattern.

activity2.title: Data Detective
steps: Ask questions based on the dataset.
Let the child guess answers using past data.

topic: Can AI Tell How You Feel?
objective: To understand how AI detects human emotions.
explanation:
• AI reads facial expressions and voice tones.
• It's used in games, customer service, and learning tools.
• It's not perfect—it guesses from clues.

activity1.title: Emoji Coder
steps: Match emotions to each face.
Discuss how AI might guess the emotion.

activity2.title: Voice Mood Test
steps: Say a sentence in happy/sad/scared tone.
Guess the emotion each time.
Discuss how tone affects meaning.

objective: To learn how AI deciphers codes and hidden patterns.
explanation:
• AI solves puzzles in text, images, or numbers.
• It breaks patterns to understand hidden messages.
• Used in cybersecurity, science, and decoding.

activity1.title: Cipher Game
steps: Replace letters using a key (e.g., A=Z).
Try to decode short words or phrases.

activity2.title: Hidden Patterns
steps: Find what repeats, what’s missing.
Explain how AI might find that too.

objective: To understand how AI decides between options.
explanation:
• AI uses rules and data to make choices.
• It looks at what happened before.
• Like a decision tree, it picks the best option.

activity1.title: Decision Tree Game
steps: Create a simple yes/no flowchart.
Use it to decide what snack to eat!

activity2.title: Choice Analyzer
steps: Discuss pros and cons of each option.
Choose like an AI based on logic.

topic: AI and the Power of Words
objective: To explore how AI understands and generates language.
explanation:
• AI reads and writes based on word patterns.
• Used in translations, chatbots, and writing tools.
• Learns language from huge datasets.

activity1.title: Talk Like a Bot
steps: Rearrange words like a chatbot might.
Try giving simple AI-like replies.

activity2.title: Predict My Word
steps: Ask child to guess the next word in a phrase.
Compare with AI-generated completions.

objective: To learn how AI can be fooled with wrong data.
explanation:
• AI trusts its training data too much.
• If tricked, it can make mistakes.
• This is why testing AI is important.

activity1.title: Fool the Robot
steps: Show examples where AI might fail.
Ask why it could be confused.

activity2.title: Spot the Error
steps: Look for odd or misplaced items.
Discuss how AI might react.

objective: To explain how AI uses loops to repeat tasks.
explanation:
• Loops help AI do jobs again and again.
• Saves time and increases speed.
• Used in games, robots, and software.

activity1.title: Loop Dance
steps: Create 3 dance steps and repeat 3 times.
Show how loops save instructions.

activity2.title: Code the Repeater
steps: Write a fake AI rule (e.g., jump 2x, turn left).
Repeat actions using loops.

objective: To explore how AI interprets images and shapes.
explanation:
• AI “sees” using data from pixels.
• It turns images into numbers and patterns.
• Used in face recognition and object detection.

activity1.title: Shape Scanner
steps: Point to items and explain how AI might label them.
Use boxes to show “detection.”

activity2.title: Pixel Puzzle
steps: Draw a simple image using colored squares.
Talk about how AI reads pixel data.

objective: To explore how robots use decision trees to choose actions.
explanation:
• Robots use a kind of “if this, then that” logic. 
 • This helps them choose what to do. 
 • It’s called a decision tree.

activity1.title: Decision Tree Drawing
steps: Create a simple robot scenario (e.g., cleaning room).
Draw a tree of choices: If room is dirty → clean.
Add more “if” paths.

activity2.title: Choice Machine
steps: Present a situation (e.g., it’s raining).
Pick correct response card using “if-then” logic.
Build chains of choices.

objective: To understand how AI tries to learn like the human brain.
explanation:
• Neural networks are made of layers that learn patterns. 
 • Each layer passes information to the next. 
 • That’s how AI recognizes things.

activity1.title: AI Layer Stack
steps: Stack blocks as input, hidden, output layers.
Pass a message through each.
Each layer “transforms” it.

activity2.title: Pattern Teacher
steps: Show patterns to child.
Let them “train” a pretend AI to recognize it.
Add variations over time.

objective: To learn how AI remembers important details.
explanation:
• AI has something like memory, called weights. 
 • It helps AI “remember” what is important. 
 • These are adjusted as AI learns.

activity1.title: Memory Match AI-Style
steps: Play memory match, but assign “weights” to each card.
Try to guess which will be remembered more.

activity2.title: Weighted Choices
steps: Assign different “importance” to jars.
Drop marbles based on what’s most important.
Adjust as you go.

objective: To understand the role of feedback in AI learning.
explanation:
• AI gets better by checking mistakes. 
 • Feedback tells it if it was right or wrong. 
 • This helps AI improve.

activity1.title: Yes-No Trainer
steps: Play teacher-student: AI guesses, child gives feedback.
Use yes/no until AI gets better.

activity2.title: AI Draws Again
steps: AI (you) draws something.
Child gives clues to improve it.
Repeat until it’s accurate.

objective: To learn how AI understands speech and sounds.
explanation:
• AI hears using microphones. 
 • It breaks sound into pieces. 
 • Then it learns what words mean.

activity1.title: Sound Splitter
steps: Listen to different sounds.
Break them into short “chunks.”
Guess what each part might mean.

activity2.title: Voice Guess Game
steps: Speak a sentence in different tones.
Child guesses meaning or feeling.
AI does the same with sound.

objective: To learn that AI makes mistakes and how it learns from them.
explanation:
• AI can give wrong answers. 
 • Mistakes help AI improve. 
 • Like humans, it learns over time.

activity1.title: Spot the Error
steps: Show cards, ask child to guess which is AI’s wrong answer.
Discuss why it might have made that mistake.

activity2.title: Correct the Robot
steps: Give robot incorrect instructions on purpose.
Let child fix the steps.
Repeat with variations.

objective: To understand what makes an AI assistant useful.
explanation:
• AI helpers answer questions or do tasks. 
 • They learn from use. 
 • Good helpers are trained well.

activity1.title: Design an Assistant
steps: Draw a pretend smart assistant.
List what it should know and do.

activity2.title: Command Game
steps: Take turns being the AI.
Follow short voice commands quickly.
Improve speed and accuracy.

objective: To explore how AI detects emotions in speech.
explanation:
• AI listens to voice tones. 
 • It can tell happy, sad, angry. 
 • This is called emotion recognition.

activity1.title: Feel the Voice
steps: Read sentences in different tones.
Child matches to correct emotion card.

activity2.title: Emotion Spotting
steps: Listen to short clips.
Guess the emotion being expressed.
Discuss how AI would guess.

objective: To understand how AI creates text based on training.
explanation:
• AI reads lots of text to learn. 
 • Then it writes based on patterns. 
 • It's like creative copying.

activity1.title: AI Story Chain
steps: Start a story.
Let child write next line.
Alternate like AI prediction.

activity2.title: Predict the Next Line
steps: Hide the last line.
Let child guess what comes next.
Reveal AI’s version after.

objective: To learn how AI creates original-looking artwork.
explanation:
• AI is trained on images and styles. 
 • It creates new images by mixing them. 
 • This is called generative AI.

activity1.title: Style Mixer
steps: Show two styles of art.
Mix styles in a new drawing.
Pretend to be an AI generator.

activity2.title: AI Draws Too
steps: Compare AI-made art with child's.
Discuss how both are creative.

objective: To explore how AI improves itself through learning.
explanation:
• Some AI learns from mistakes and gets better. 
 • It tries again and again to improve. 
 • This is called machine learning.

activity1.title: Learning Maze
steps: Try solving the maze.
Mark the wrong paths.
Try again using the new path.

activity2.title: AI Mistake Fixer
materials: List of simple math or logic errors.
steps: Pretend to be an AI fixing mistakes.
Find and fix each one.

objective: To understand how AI processes human language.
explanation:
• Some AI understands and talks with people. 
 • This is called natural language processing. 
 • It helps AI answer questions and chat.

activity1.title: Chatbot Roleplay
steps: Take turns being a chatbot.
Use simple, clear answers.
Switch roles.

activity2.title: Fix the Message
materials: Sentences with jumbled or missing words.
steps: Rearrange or complete the messages.
Think like a chatbot fixing inputs.

objective: To see how AI understands photos and videos.
explanation:
• AI can look at pictures and tell what’s inside. 
 • It sees faces, animals, or even emotions. 
 • This is called image recognition.

activity1.title: Guess the Scene
materials: Random pictures from magazines or books.
steps: Child describes what’s in each picture.
Discuss how AI might describe the same.

activity2.title: Build-a-Scene
steps: Draw a scene with lots of details.
Have a friend guess what AI might say.

objective: To learn how AI reads emotions.
explanation:
• AI can read faces to tell feelings. 
 • This is called emotion detection. 
 • It’s used in games, cars, and education.

activity1.title: Face Mood Mirror
steps: Make a happy face, sad face, etc.
Describe each one.
Imagine how AI would read it.

activity2.title: Emotion Match
steps: Match emoji with real expressions.
Discuss how AI links them.

objective: To learn about how AI follows instructions.
explanation:
• AI uses code to act and decide. 
 • It follows logic like “if this, then that.” 
 • Simple rules can create smart actions.

activity1.title: Code Me!
steps: Give child commands like a robot: “If I clap, spin.”
Add more “if-then” steps.

activity2.title: Make-A-Code
steps: Write 3 simple “if-then” rules.
Test them on someone else.

objective: To understand neural networks.
explanation:
• AI has “brains” made of nodes. 
 • These connect like a web. 
 • Together, they make decisions.

activity1.title: Node Web Game
steps: Label circles as inputs and outputs.
Connect with string to show network.

activity2.title: Puzzle Decision
steps: Choose paths by linking ideas.
Mimic how AI narrows choices.

objective: To explore AI’s decision speed.
explanation:
• AI checks tons of choices quickly. 
 • It uses data to pick the best one. 
 • Speed helps in games, driving, and safety.

activity1.title: Quick Think Race
steps: Ask fast questions like “Which is taller?”
Child answers in 3 seconds.

activity2.title: Data Sorter
steps: Sort items into yes/no piles.
Add time pressure.

objective: To understand how AI remembers patterns.
explanation:
• AI remembers what it sees often. 
 • This helps it predict or suggest things. 
 • Like remembering your favorites.

activity1.title: Repeat Finder
steps: Show patterns, then hide.
Ask what repeats.

activity2.title: Suggestion Bot
steps: Pick favorite colors, foods, etc.
Suggest new things based on past.

objective: To connect AI to real-world adventures.
explanation:
• AI can be part of solving problems. 
 • Think of it as a teammate in a story. 
 • Encourages imagination and logic.

activity1.title: Hero and AI
steps: Write a short story where AI helps a hero.
Act it out.

activity2.title: Choose Your AI
steps: Pick an AI to help in a problem.
Explain the choice.

objective: To think about ethics and choices in AI.
explanation:
• Should AI make all choices? 
 • Who decides what is right? 
 • Talk about fairness and responsibility.

activity1.title: AI Choice Debate
steps: Read a situation.
Ask: should AI decide or humans?
Discuss reasons.

activity2.title: Build a Fair Bot
steps: Draw a fair AI character.
List its rules.

objective: To understand how AI predicts future actions.
explanation:
• AI uses past data to guess what might happen. 
 • It helps in things like weather and traffic. 
 • The more it learns, the better it predicts.

activity1.title: Pattern Prophet
steps: Make a pattern like red-red-blue.
Hide the last one and ask child to predict it.
Add more complex patterns.

activity2.title: Future Forecast
steps: Show past 3 days of weather.
Ask child to guess tomorrow’s weather.
Discuss how AI uses more data.

objective: To explore how machines try to "think" like humans.
explanation:
• AI mimics the brain using artificial neurons. 
 • It makes decisions and solves problems. 
 • It's called a neural network.

activity1.title: Neural Path Maze
materials: Paper maze or printed brain path.
steps: Let child trace a decision path.
Add options and outcomes at each fork.
Show how AI chooses based on past.

activity2.title: Memory Builder
steps: Show a pattern of 5 cards.
Ask child to recall or guess next.
Talk about how AI uses "memory."

objective: To show how AI mimics human senses.
explanation:
• AI can see, hear, touch, smell, and taste in different ways. 
 • It uses sensors and data to sense like humans. 
 • Not perfect, but improving.

activity1.title: Sound Sorter
steps: Play different animal or object sounds.
Ask child to name and sort them.
Talk about AI voice recognition.

activity2.title: Taste Test AI
steps: Blindfold child and ask them to guess taste.
Talk about how AI might "sense" flavor.
Compare accuracy.

objective: To understand how AI learns from mistakes.
explanation:
• AI makes mistakes, then adjusts. 
 • It needs feedback to improve. 
 • This is called training.

activity1.title: Spot the Glitch
steps: Show AI-designed patterns with a flaw.
Ask child to find and correct them.
Discuss how AI is corrected.

activity2.title: Fix the Robot
steps: Make the robot do a wrong action.
Ask child to suggest a fix.
Try again.

objective: To explore how AI reads feelings.
explanation:
• AI uses face, voice, and words to guess emotion. 
 • Not always accurate. 
 • Helps in games and care.

activity1.title: Guess That Mood
steps: Show a card and ask child to mimic it.
Talk about how AI might read this.
Discuss challenges.

activity2.title: Feeling Sort
steps: Group by happy, sad, angry, etc.
Compare how AI might label them.
Talk about mistakes AI can make.

objective: To learn how AI solves puzzles and games.
explanation:
• AI plays games by using rules and patterns. 
 • It keeps trying until it wins. 
 • This is a way of learning.

activity1.title: Bot Puzzle Master
steps: Start puzzle, give AI-style hints.
Use if-then steps.
Discuss how bots do it faster.

activity2.title: Try-Fail-Win
steps: Attempt different paths.
Mark fails, retry better.
Note what was learned.

objective: To show how AI makes and learns music.
explanation:
• AI listens and creates music. 
 • It can remix or write new songs. 
 • It learns from many samples.

activity1.title: Rhythm AI
steps: Tap out a beat.
Ask child to predict next rhythm.
Talk about AI pattern learning.

activity2.title: Compose Me!
steps: Let child add sounds and create tune.
Add “AI suggestions” like faster/slower.
Compare versions.

objective: To explore voice recognition by AI.
explanation:
• AI hears and knows who is speaking. 
 • Each voice has a unique print. 
 • It helps with security and assistants.

activity1.title: Voice Match
steps: Play clips and guess the speaker.
Compare with AI voice tech.
Discuss voice prints.

activity2.title: Say the Secret
steps: Child says phrase in different voices.
Talk about voice unlocking.
Try saying it wrong.

objective: To understand how AI sees and detects.
explanation:
• AI uses cameras to detect faces, shapes, or colors. 
 • It’s used in phones, cars, and more. 
 • Called computer vision.

activity1.title: Object Finder
steps: Show picture of item.
Ask child to find matching object.
Mimic how AI scans for matches.

activity2.title: Color Coder
steps: Give sorting challenge by color.
Add twist like sort only red & green.
Show how AI filters by input.

objective: To learn how humans train AI.
explanation:
• AI learns from examples we give. 
 • Good data = smart AI. 
 • Bad data = confused AI.

activity1.title: Right or Wrong
steps: Show cat picture and say “cat.”
Show dog and say “cat” (wrong).
Ask child what AI would learn.

activity2.title: Feed the Bot
materials: Toy with open mouth or bin.
steps: Give toy good items (food), then bad (trash).
Discuss what it should learn.
Compare results.

objective: To introduce the idea of selling and buying.
explanation:
• Shops are places where people buy things. 
 • Shopkeepers help us choose and pay. 
 • Some kids also pretend to run shops.

activity1.title: Toy Shop Setup
steps: Set up a pretend shop with toys.
Child plays as shopkeeper, you play as buyer.

activity2.title: Price Match Game
steps: Show item card and ask child to match with correct price.
Use simple numbers.

objective: To understand making and selling something.
explanation:
• People can make things and sell them. 
 • Lemonade is a simple thing kids can pretend to sell. 
 • Selling teaches sharing and helping.

activity1.title: Pretend Lemonade Stand
steps: Child sets up a lemonade stand with pretend items.
Invite family to “buy.”

activity2.title: Decorate & Advertise
steps: Make signs to attract customers.
Decorate stand with fun stickers.

objective: To learn about money used in business.
explanation:
• Coins are used to buy and sell. 
 • Different coins have different values. 
 • Entrepreneurs need to understand money.

activity1.title: Coin Sorting
steps: Sort coins by size or color.
Talk about how coins are used to buy.

activity2.title: Coin Store Game
steps: Set price for each toy.
Child “buys” with coins.

objective: To introduce the idea of building a small market.
explanation:
• Markets are places with many small sellers. 
 • Each box can be a shop with items. 
 • Kids can learn to organize and display.

activity1.title: Market Setup
steps: Set up different box stalls.
Each stall has something to “sell.”

activity2.title: Market Walk
steps: Child walks around choosing items.
Practice saying “How much?” or “Thank you.”

objective: To explore the idea of exchanging things.
explanation:
• People trade when they don’t use money. 
 • You give something and get something back. 
 • Fair trade helps everyone.

activity1.title: Toy Swap
steps: Offer one toy and ask for a trade.
Talk about why the trade is fair.

activity2.title: Snack Trade
steps: Trade snack types with each other.
Discuss if both are happy with it.

objective: To introduce the concept of having business ideas.
explanation:
• Entrepreneurs start with ideas. 
 • An idea can be a toy, game, or service. 
 • Even kids can think of fun ideas.

activity1.title: What's Your Idea?
steps: Ask child to think of fun things to “sell.”
Write or draw ideas and put in the box.

activity2.title: Pick & Act
steps: Pick a slip and act it out.
Pretend to make or sell the idea.

objective: To understand the importance of customers.
explanation:
• Customers are people who buy. 
 • Good sellers listen and help. 
 • Happy customers return.

activity1.title: Be a Helpful Seller
steps: Child pretends to sell.
You ask for help and smile if they help.

activity2.title: Happy Shopper
steps: Give a sticker if child is polite while selling.
Celebrate good service.

objective: To show how people make and sell services.
explanation:
• Not all entrepreneurs sell things—some build or help. 
 • Services include cleaning, fixing, or teaching. 
 • Helping others is a kind of work too.

activity1.title: Fix-It Pretend
steps: Pretend to fix the broken toy.
Act like a builder or fixer.

activity2.title: Helper Badge
steps: Give a badge when child helps fix or clean.
Pretend they earned it like a helper.

objective: To recognize money as something people use.
explanation:
• Money can be coins or paper. 
 • Some money looks different in color and size. 
 • It helps us pay and trade.

activity1.title: Make Play Money
steps: Cut paper into notes.
Draw numbers and symbols.

activity2.title: Use It to Buy
steps: Use created money to buy toys in pretend play.
Practice paying and receiving.

objective: To learn how businesses tell people about their products.
explanation:
• Ads help people know what’s for sale. 
 • You can draw, talk, or act to advertise. 
 • Creative ads attract buyers.

activity1.title: Draw an Ad
steps: Draw a poster showing your pretend shop or product.
Hang it up proudly.

activity2.title: Talk Show Seller
steps: Pretend you’re on TV selling the product.
Say why it’s great and useful.

objective: To help children learn about simple business ideas.
explanation:
• A lemonade stand is a tiny business. 
 • It sells drinks to people. 
 • It teaches how to offer something useful.

activity1.title: Lemonade Stand Play
steps: Set up a pretend lemonade stall.
Invite family to “buy.”
Use play money to sell.

activity2.title: Sell Me Something
steps: Choose a toy to “sell.”
Explain why someone should buy it.
Practice “selling.”

objective: To teach the concept of saving money.
explanation:
• Entrepreneurs save money to use later. 
 • A jar is a simple way to save. 
 • Saving helps in buying something bigger later.

activity1.title: Save and Watch
steps: Add coins to the jar daily.
Watch it fill up.
Talk about saving.

activity2.title: Picture Your Goal
steps: Draw what you want to save for.
Place it on or near the jar.
Talk about how saving gets you closer.

objective: To show how everyday things can become a business.
explanation:
• Businesses often begin with small ideas. 
 • A simple craft or treat can be shared. 
 • Kids can learn to think of ideas.

activity1.title: What Can This Be?
steps: Show an item and ask “What could we make with this?”
Let child build something new.
Talk about its use.

activity2.title: Pretend Product Pitch
steps: Pretend to “sell” the created item.
Talk about what it does.
Use imagination.

objective: To teach about sharing and kindness in business.
explanation:
• Some businesses also help people. 
 • Giving and kindness are part of good entrepreneurship. 
 • You can “sell” for free!

activity1.title: Gift Shop Roleplay
steps: Set up a pretend shop.
Invite family to choose an item “for free.”
Wrap and “give” it.

activity2.title: Thank You Cards
steps: Make simple thank-you cards.
Give them to family or friends.
Talk about why gratitude matters.

objective: To introduce the idea of planning before doing.
explanation:
• Entrepreneurs make a plan before they start. 
 • Planning saves time and effort. 
 • Even play needs a plan!

activity1.title: Build-a-Plan
steps: Before building, draw what you want to make.
Then build it with blocks.
Compare plan vs. real build.

activity2.title: My Business Map
steps: Draw a simple shop or service idea.
Walk through the steps.

objective: To practice speaking with purpose.
explanation:
• Entrepreneurs explain ideas clearly. 
 • Speaking helps sell, lead, and share. 
 • Practice helps children speak with power.

activity1.title: Toy Talk
steps: Ask child to introduce the toy as if it’s a new product.
Share features and why others should want it.
Practice fun voice tones.

activity2.title: Mirror Speech
steps: Child speaks in front of mirror.
Give a simple “business pitch.”
Smile, stand tall, and speak slow.

objective: To help children learn about value.
explanation:
• Everything in business has a price. 
 • Prices depend on how useful or fun something is. 
 • Kids can learn to choose prices.

activity1.title: Price Tag Game
steps: Assign play prices to toys.
Talk about why one costs more.
Rearrange and discuss.

activity2.title: Guess the Price
steps: Show item and ask child to guess price.
Say the real price.
Talk about what makes things expensive or cheap.

objective: To explore team spirit and roles.
explanation:
• Business people work in teams. 
 • Each role matters. 
 • Kids can learn to cooperate.

activity1.title: Team Cleanup
steps: Divide roles: picker, stacker, checker.
Clean up as a “team.”
Praise each role.

activity2.title: Role Play Market
steps: Assign roles: seller, shopper, helper.
Play “market.”
Switch roles.

objective: To teach about branding and symbols.
explanation:
• A logo is a picture that shows what a business is. 
 • Good logos are simple and easy to remember. 
 • Kids can make their own logos.

activity1.title: My Logo
steps: Ask child to think of a pretend shop.
Draw a logo for it.
Color and display it.

activity2.title: Guess the Logo
steps: Show logos and guess what they sell.
Talk about colors and shapes.
Make up new meanings.

objective: To introduce storytelling in business.
explanation:
• Entrepreneurs tell stories to share ideas. 
 • A story makes people listen and care. 
 • Kids can learn to create and share simple stories.

activity1.title: Create-a-Story
steps: Pick a toy or picture.
Make up a story about it helping someone.
Share the story.

activity2.title: Story Swap
steps: One person starts a story idea.
Child adds the next line.
Go back and forth.

objective: To understand money pieces and their value.
explanation: • Money comes in coins and notes. • Each has a different value. • Entrepreneurs know how to count money.

activity1.title: Coin Match Hunt
steps: Spread coins on a table.
Child matches each coin to value chart.

activity2.title: Build a Coin Shop
steps: Child “sells” items for coins.
Practice making change with help.

objective: To learn product presentation.
explanation: • Presentation makes products attractive. • Colors and arrangement matter. • Entrepreneurs create displays that sell.

activity1.title: Make a Mini Stand
steps: Set up a small colorful display.
Arrange items by color.

activity2.title: Favorite Color Shop
materials: Toys or drawings of different colors.
steps: Child picks toys of one color to “sell.”
Role-play selling only that color.

objective: To value time and manage it for tasks.
explanation: • Entrepreneurs use time wisely. • Time helps plan work and breaks. • Scheduling improves results.

activity1.title: Morning Planner
steps: Make a list of 3 tasks to do in the morning.
Use drawings or stickers to check them off.

activity2.title: Time Puzzle Game
steps: Match times with picture tasks (e.g., brush teeth at 7).
Set clock to that time.

objective: To spark imagination for creating ideas.
explanation: • Every business starts with an idea. • Entrepreneurs imagine and explore. • Ideas can come from fun and play.

activity1.title: Wear Your Idea
steps: Decorate hat with an “idea” (e.g., a flying toy).
Explain it to a friend or parent.

activity2.title: Guess My Invention
steps: Draw a fun invention.
Others guess what it does.

objective: To understand who customers are.
explanation: • A customer buys or uses a product. • Entrepreneurs think about what people like. • Happy customers return.

activity1.title: Who’s the Customer?
steps: Pick a “customer” card.
Choose the best toy for them.

activity2.title: Happy Store
steps: “Serve” toys to a pretend customer.
Say polite phrases like “Thank you!”

objective: To explore logos and branding.
explanation: • Logos help people remember brands. • Shapes, letters, and colors matter. • Entrepreneurs design their own symbols.

activity1.title: Find the Logos
steps: Point out logos in daily items.
Talk about which are easy to remember.

activity2.title: Make Your Own Logo
steps: Child draws a logo for their name or toy shop.
Explain what it shows.

objective: To role-play business with snacks.
explanation: • Simple businesses start small. • Snacks are easy to sell and serve. • Entrepreneurs learn by doing.

activity1.title: Set Up a Snack Table
materials: Empty snack boxes or real snacks.
steps: Arrange a pretend table with snack items.
Practice “selling” and “buying.”

activity2.title: Price It Right
steps: Assign prices to snacks.
Child uses play money to buy.

objective: To imagine how shops are built.
explanation: • Store layout affects what people buy. • Entrepreneurs plan where things go. • Good design makes shopping fun.

activity1.title: Shop Floor Plan
steps: Draw where shelves, doors, and signs go.
Walk fingers through the shop path.

activity2.title: Build a Mini Store
steps: Use blocks to make shelves and counters.
Place items carefully.

objective: To explore work people do.
explanation: • Jobs are ways people earn and help others. • Entrepreneurs sometimes do many jobs. • Knowing jobs sparks ideas.

activity1.title: Job Charades
steps: Act out different jobs (e.g., baker, driver).
Others guess the job.

activity2.title: Draw My Future Job
steps: Draw self doing a fun job.
Talk about what tools are used.

objective: To learn about exchanging work or things.
explanation: • People can trade or earn by helping. • Work has value. • Entrepreneurs know when to give and take.

activity1.title: Help for a Reward
steps: Do a helpful task (e.g., clean toys).
Earn a sticker or a coin.

activity2.title: Trade Game
steps: Child trades a toy with someone.
Talk about fairness.

objective: To understand how markets work.
explanation: • Markets are places to buy and sell. • Entrepreneurs prepare for market days. • Good planning helps sales.

activity1.title: Market Stall Setup
steps: Arrange a market stall with items.
Practice greeting customers and selling.

activity2.title: Price Tag Fun
steps: Create price tags for items.
Discuss how prices are decided.

objective: To learn the importance of saving money.
explanation: • Saving helps us buy what we want later. • Entrepreneurs save to grow their business. • Jars can help us keep money safe.

activity1.title: Decorate a Savings Jar
steps: Decorate the jar.
Put play money or coins inside.

activity2.title: Save or Spend Game
steps: Decide to save or spend on cards.
Talk about choices.

objective: To understand working together.
explanation: • Entrepreneurs often work in teams. • Teamwork helps solve problems. • Sharing ideas makes work easier.

activity1.title: Build a Tower Together
steps: Build a tall tower as a team.
Share ideas and help each other.

activity2.title: Team Drawing
steps: Take turns drawing parts of a picture.
Discuss the final art.

objective: To create a story to sell a product.
explanation: • Stories help explain why products are special. • Entrepreneurs tell stories to attract customers. • Stories make products memorable.

activity1.title: Make a Product Story
steps: Create a story about the product’s uses.
Tell the story to family or friends.

activity2.title: Story Poster
steps: Draw a poster showing the story highlights.
Display it at “store.”

objective: To learn how to be kind to customers.
explanation: • Happy customers come back. • Saying thank you matters. • Entrepreneurs listen to customers.

activity1.title: Thank You Cards
steps: Make thank you cards for customers.
Write or draw kind messages.

activity2.title: Role Play Service
steps: Act as shopkeeper and customer.
Practice polite words and listening.

objective: To see how packaging attracts buyers.
explanation: • Packaging protects products. • It can be colorful and fun. • Entrepreneurs choose packaging carefully.

activity1.title: Wrap a Toy
steps: Wrap a small toy like a gift.
Decorate the package.

activity2.title: Design a Box
steps: Draw or color on a box to show product use.
Explain your design.

objective: To introduce simple budgeting ideas.
explanation: • Budgeting means planning money use. • Entrepreneurs watch income and spending. • It helps avoid running out of money.

activity1.title: Plan a Mini Budget
steps: Decide how to spend or save money.
Write down the plan.

activity2.title: Budget Role Play
steps: Pretend to buy items within a set budget.
Keep track of spending.

objective: To recognize who helps in a business.
explanation: • Businesses have helpers like suppliers and helpers. • Everyone has an important role. • Teamwork makes business grow.

activity1.title: Who Helps?
materials: Pictures of different helpers or people.
steps: Match helpers with their jobs.
Talk about why they are important.

activity2.title: Thank a Helper
steps: Draw a helper and say thank you.
Share drawing with family or friends.

objective: To learn about asking people’s opinions.
explanation: • Surveys help know what customers want. • Entrepreneurs ask questions before selling. • Listening helps improve products.

activity1.title: Make a Survey
steps: Write 3 simple questions (like favorite toy).
Ask family or friends and note answers.

activity2.title: Survey Poster
steps: Draw pictures showing survey results.
Share with others.

objective: To create catchy business names.
explanation: • Business names tell what the business is about. • Creative names attract customers. • Names should be easy to remember.

activity1.title: Name Your Business
steps: Think of a name for a pretend business.
Draw a logo or sign.

activity2.title: Name Game
steps: Combine words to make fun business names.
Share with friends or family.

objective: To spark creative business ideas.
explanation: • Entrepreneurs start with a great idea. • Ideas can come from everyday things. • Creativity helps find new solutions.

activity1.title: Idea Brainstorm
steps: Draw or write as many business ideas as possible.
Share ideas with family or friends.

activity2.title: Idea Mix-Up
steps: Pick two random cards and combine to make a new business idea.
Discuss if it’s fun or useful.

objective: To learn how to test products before selling.
explanation: • Testing helps find what works best. • Entrepreneurs check if customers like their product. • Feedback leads to improvements.

activity1.title: Taste Test
steps: Make a small snack or product.
Let family taste and give opinions.

activity2.title: Product Trial
steps: Let friends try the product.
Note what they like or don’t like.

objective: To deepen understanding of budgeting.
explanation: • Budgets keep spending on track. • Entrepreneurs plan to save and spend wisely. • Budgeting helps meet goals.

activity1.title: Create a Budget Chart
steps: Make a chart with income and expenses.
Use play money to fill in amounts.

activity2.title: Budget Scenario Game
steps: Pick cards to create a budget.
See if budget balances or needs changes.

objective: To emphasize friendly customer service.
explanation: • Good manners keep customers happy. • Listening and helping build trust. • Happy customers spread good words.

activity1.title: Customer Role Play
steps: Take turns as seller and buyer practicing kind words.
Practice listening carefully.

activity2.title: Thank You Poster
steps: Make a poster thanking customers.
Display at a pretend store.

objective: To understand simple market research.
explanation: • Research helps know what customers want. • Entrepreneurs ask and listen before selling. • Research improves business success.

explanation: • Attractive packaging draws attention. • Good packaging protects products. • Packaging shows brand style.

explanation: • Businesses work best with teamwork. • Sharing ideas helps solve problems. • Everyone’s role is important.

explanation: • Prices cover costs and make profit. • Fair pricing attracts customers. • Entrepreneurs think about costs and value.

explanation: • Ads tell why products are special. • Bright colors and fun words attract attention. • Entrepreneurs use ads to sell.

explanation: • Celebrating motivates people. • Success can be small or big. • Entrepreneurs reward hard work.

explanation: • Businesses begin with planning. • Steps include idea, money, making, and selling. • A clear path helps reach goals.

activity2.title: Step Match Game

explanation: • Entrepreneurs make important decisions. • Being a leader means guiding a team. • Good leaders listen and help.

Practice giving kind instructions.

activity2.title: Lead a Challenge
steps: Lead a group to finish the task.
Ensure everyone joins in.

objective: To understand branding and personal identity.
explanation: • A brand shows what a business stands for. • Logos, names, and colors show identity. • Entrepreneurs choose how people see them.

steps: Create a logo for a pretend business.

activity2.title: Brand Board

objective: To discover how entrepreneurs solve problems.
explanation: • Great businesses solve real problems. • Finding a need helps create ideas. • Listening leads to better solutions.

activity1.title: Problem Detectives

activity2.title: Solution Skits
steps: Act out a problem and show how a product can help.

objective: To notice businesses in everyday life.
explanation: • Businesses are all around us. • Each one offers a product or service. • Observing them gives learning ideas.

activity1.title: Local Store Tour
steps: Walk around and note nearby businesses.
Observe what they sell or do.

activity2.title: Business Drawing
steps: Draw your favorite local shop or service.

objective: To explore how prices are set.
explanation: • Price includes cost, effort, and value. • Too high or low affects business. • Entrepreneurs compare before pricing.

activity2.title: Value Guess
steps: Guess price of each item.
Compare with real prices.

objective: To recognize the roles people play in a business.
explanation: • Businesses need many roles. • Team members include makers, sellers, and helpers. • Cooperation makes business run well.

activity2.title: Business Puzzle

objective: To practice designing a business space.
explanation: • Store layout affects customers. • Displays make shopping easy and fun. • Good design increases interest.

activity2.title: Floor Plan Fun

objective: To understand the art of selling.
explanation: • Selling is about showing why something is useful. • Being kind and honest builds trust. • Knowing your product helps.

activity2.title: Buyer’s Choice

explanation: • Entrepreneurs can share success. • Giving helps community. • Business can have purpose beyond money.

• Trends are patterns people follow, like fashion or toys.

• Spotting a trend early can help in business.

• It helps build useful products.

• It gets improved, made, and sold.

objective: To explore how businesses create identity.

explanation:

objective: To explore how trends shape business ideas.
explanation:
• Trends are what people like or follow.

explanation:
• Price depends on cost, value, and audience. 
 • Entrepreneurs must balance profit and fairness. 
 • Thinking through pricing builds smart decision-making.

objective: To learn how brands create identity.
explanation:
• Brands use logos, colors, and names to be memorable. 
 • A strong brand creates trust and excitement.

• Many businesses start with solving a problem.

 • Entrepreneurs must study what works and why. 
 • Learning from others helps plan smarter businesses.

List key lessons learned.

steps: Take a business that didn’t succeed.
Redesign its plan or branding.

Write down what they feel, need, and want.

Test it with a friend or adult.

explanation:
• Business has changed over time—from barter to online stores. 
 • Knowing history helps plan the future. 
 • Kids can imagine what businesses might look like tomorrow.

activity1.title: Business Timeline
steps: Place key types of businesses on a timeline.
Add images or symbols.

activity2.title: Future Storefront

Draw its logo, tools, and customers.
Explain how it works.

• Simulating a start-up teaches planning and execution. 
 • They learn how ideas turn into real ventures. 
 • It encourages long-term thinking.

• An MVP is the simplest version of a product.

objective: To teach how failure can lead to better ideas.
explanation:
• Entrepreneurs often fail before succeeding. 
 • Learning from mistakes helps growth. 
 • Failure builds resilience.

activity1.title: Famous Fails
materials: Cards with failed products or ideas.
steps: Read about failures (e.g. inventions, ideas).
Guess why they failed and what improved later.

activity2.title: My Oops Moment
steps: Write about a small personal failure.
Note what you learned and how you'd do it differently.

objective: To practice creating a powerful business pitch.
explanation:
• A pitch explains your idea in a short, clear way. 
 • It shows value, uniqueness, and impact. 
 • Builds public speaking and clarity.

activity1.title: 60-Second Pitch
steps: Pick a product idea.
Create a 1-minute pitch to explain it.
Time yourself and repeat to improve.

activity2.title: Pitch Parade
steps: Present your pitch to the group.
Take one question each.

objective: To learn how trends influence business.
explanation:
• Entrepreneurs look for trends to spot new ideas. 
 • Trends come from social changes, tech, or style. 
 • Timing is key to success.

activity1.title: Future Lens
steps: Read or browse for what's becoming popular.
Circle interesting new products or behaviors.

activity2.title: Trend to Idea
steps: Pick one trend spotted.
Sketch a business based on that trend.

objective: To understand how branding shapes identity.
explanation:
• Branding includes logo, colors, and message. 
 • A strong brand stands out and tells a story. 
 • It builds trust and recognition.

activity1.title: Logo Launch

activity2.title: Slogan Spark
steps: Create a catchy one-line slogan for your business.

objective: To explore businesses that solve real-world problems.
explanation:
• Social entrepreneurs mix profit with purpose. 
 • They solve problems like hunger, pollution, or access. 
 • Makes business meaningful.

activity1.title: Problem Spotter

Pick one and think of a solution.

activity2.title: Pitch for Good

objective: To understand how entrepreneurship changed over time.
explanation:
• Businesses evolve with tech and culture. 
 • Past businesses inspire new ideas. 
 • Encourages timeline thinking.

• Entrepreneurs must manage earnings and costs.
